questions.text: One of the two most recent holders of this government position in America mentions that his “surgery is criminal” in “Grafik” while the other mentions a boy and his sister “let[ting] loose at once” at “5pm on the nose” in “The Universe as Primal Scream.” Those recent holders of this position are Juan Felipe Herrera and Tracy K. Smith. People who hold this position in the US receive a stipend to continue their work endowed by a gift from Archer M. Huntington. Other people who have served in this position in the US, which has an office administered by the Centre for the Book, include an author who mentions “frail, illegal fire balloons appear[ing]” in “The Armadillo” and one who mentions “pool players” at the “Golden Shovel” who “die soon” in “We Real Cool.” Holders of this position in the US, former ones of which include Elizabeth Bishop and Gwendolyn Brooks, are appointed by a figure who also awards the Gershwin Prize for Popular Song. For ten points, name this position that, in the US, helps the Library of Congress to promote the reading of and writing of works by authors who sometimes use rhyme and metre.

questions.first_sentence: This work, reinterpreted by Peter Straub into the story “Mr. Clubb and Mr. Cuff,” mentions the Joseph Priestly work The Doctrine of Philosophical Necessity, which the narrator says “induce[s] a salutary feeling.
questions.text: This work, reinterpreted by Peter Straub into the story “Mr. Clubb and Mr. Cuff,” mentions the Joseph Priestly work The Doctrine of Philosophical Necessity, which the narrator says “induce[s] a salutary feeling.” The narrator mentions that the main setting of this work is divided into two parts by a glass wall, and one character, who shares his name with an Anatolian country, asks the narrator if he should “black [the] eyes” of the title character. After attending the Trinity Church one Sunday, the narrator finds the title character in his place of business and describes him as “Marius brooding among the ruins of Carthage” before commenting on the fact that he and the narrator shared a “fraternal melancholy” as “sons of Adam.” When that perhaps depressed title character dies in the Halls of Justice, the narrator says that he sleeps “with kings and counsellors” and compares him to humanity. For ten points, name this “story of Wall Street” whose title character, formerly employed at the Dead Letter Office, repeatedly states “I would prefer not to.”

questions.first_sentence: One ambulance driver during this conflict wrote of “bring[ing] the fragment/of my prayer” to the “Moon of the Unrevealed” and was the nephew of J.P. Morgan Jr.
questions.text: One ambulance driver during this conflict wrote of “bring[ing] the fragment/of my prayer” to the “Moon of the Unrevealed” and was the nephew of J.P. Morgan Jr. Another ambulance driver during this conflict chronicled the lives of many authors of the Lost Generation, including himself, in his memoir Exile's Return. In addition to Harry Crosby and Malcolm Cowley, another ambulance driver during this conflict wrote about characters such as stenographer Janey Williams and actress Margo Dowling in the novels The 42nd Parallel, 1919, and The Big Money, all of which comprise his USA Trilogy. A friend of that author, also was an ambulance driver during this conflict, wrote about a person who “sang his didn’t” and “danced his did” in the poem “anyone lived in a pretty how town." Those writers were John Dos Passos and e e cummings. Another ambulance driver during this conflict wrote the posthumously published memoir A Moveable Feast, while another wrote The Making of Americans and the deceptively named Autobiography of Alice B. Toklas. That author drove ambulances during this conflict because of her inability to perform in a more active role in this conflict due to her gender. For ten points, name this conflict, in which authors such as Ernest Hemingway and Gertrude Stein transported soldiers who were wounded or had contracted sicknesses such as the Spanish Flu.

questions.first_sentence: People associated with this movement include one who asked “who were the Lion Men that walked in my dreams?
questions.text: People associated with this movement include one who asked “who were the Lion Men that walked in my dreams?” at the beginning of his poem “The Child” and one who wrote of “the sandpipers/white and black” in “Invocation and Theophany”; both of those poets often presented at the Six Gallery reading. Another poet from this movement mentioned a “white god haunting Indian dreams” in his poem “Beatitudes Visuales Mexicanas” and published the collection A Coney Island of the Mind. The musical duo who performs "Do It Again" got their name from a steam-powered adult item in a novel by an author associated with this literary movement. Another author associated with this movement wrote a novel in which one character eats only apple pie and ice cream, and a character from that novel, Carlo Marx, represents a poet associated with this movement who wrote about how everything is holy in the footnote to his most famous poem, which mentions “angelheaded hipsters” and repeats the line “I’m with you in Rockland.” For ten points, name this countercultural, San-Francisco-based literary movement, authors of which include William S. Burroughs, Jack Kerouac, and Allen Ginsberg.

questions.first_sentence: One writer who held this job wrote of “bring[ing] the fragment/of my prayer” to the “Moon of the Unrevealed” and was the nephew of J.P. Morgan Jr.; another writer who held this job chronicled the lives of many authors of the Lost Generation, including himself, in his memoir Exile's Return.
questions.text: One writer who held this job wrote of “bring[ing] the fragment/of my prayer” to the “Moon of the Unrevealed” and was the nephew of J.P. Morgan Jr.; another writer who held this job chronicled the lives of many authors of the Lost Generation, including himself, in his memoir Exile's Return. In addition to Harry Crosby and Malcolm Cowley, another author who held this job wrote about characters such as stenographer Janey Williams and actress Margo Dowling in the novels The 42nd Parallel, 1919, and The Big Money, all of which comprise his USA Trilogy. A friend of that author wrote about a person who “sang his didn’t” and “danced his did” in the poem “anyone lived in a pretty how town”; that author, e e cummings, and John Dos Passos, his friend, performed this job soon after graduating from Harvard. One author who had this job wrote the posthumously published memoir A Moveable Feast, while another author who held this job wrote The Making of Americans and the deceptively named Autobiography of Alice B. Toklas about her lover; that author held this job because of her inability to perform in a more active role due to her gender, as did authors who were too young or old to do so. For ten points, name this job held by authors such as Ernest Hemingway and Gertrude Stein in which they transported soldiers who were wounded or had contracted sicknesses such as the Spanish Flu.

questions.first_sentence: It is tall and huge. It comes from the ancient world. It looks triangular.
questions.text: It is tall and huge. It comes from the ancient world. It looks triangular. We don't know how it was built.

questions.first_sentence: A poisonous herbaceous plant native to Europe and North Africa, that has a green stem streaked with red or purple.
questions.text: A poisonous herbaceous plant native to Europe and North Africa, that has a green stem streaked with red or purple. When ingested this plant disrupts the workings of the central nervous system and can be lethal to both humans and livestock. In ancient Greece, this poisonous plant was commonly used to kill prisoners. Finally, what poisonous plant did Socrates consume upon being condemned to die?

questions.first_sentence: Sequence prediction attacks can be prevented in this protocol by choosing random initial sequence numbers in three way handshakes conducted by SYN and ACK packets.
questions.text: Sequence prediction attacks can be prevented in this protocol by choosing random initial sequence numbers in three way handshakes conducted by SYN and ACK packets. The urgent pointer in this protocol marks data to be processed immediately. This protocol offers higher accuracy, but also higher latency, in contrast to (*) the User Datagram Protocol. For 10 points, name this network transport protocol commonly paired with IP.

questions.first_sentence: This Athenian Philosopher assisted in laying the foundation of Western philosophy.
questions.text: This Athenian Philosopher assisted in laying the foundation of Western philosophy. The student of Socrates and teacher of Aristotle is famous for his many allegories such as The Allegory of The Cave. Who is the Greek philosopher, author of The Republic?

questions.first_sentence: The oldest veteran of the Crimean War was one of these animals.
questions.text: The oldest veteran of the Crimean War was one of these animals. That specimen, Timothy, recently died at Powderham Castle. In Chinese folklore, a black one of these animals, along with a snake, symbolizes longevity. According to Terry Prachetts's Discworld series, Discworld floats through space ont he back of one of these animals. A popular anti-Embargo Act cartoon depicts one of these animals named O-grab-me. For then points, name this hard shelled animal of the order Testudines.

questions.first_sentence: Layers of enamel, topped by black, on a dark blue background symbolizing the sky in this artist's Reflection of Big Dipper.
questions.text: Layers of enamel, topped by black, on a dark blue background symbolizing the sky in this artist's Reflection of Big Dipper. In a 1999 study, Richard Taylor named this painter's style as fractals expressionism. He's known for adding foreign materials to his work such as sand or glass shards, the latter can be seen on Blue Poles. For 10 points--name this painter who painted Full Fathom Five and known as "Jack The Dripper"?

questions.first_sentence: A constitution enacted in 1889 forbids female from assuming this role, despite eight female have before.
questions.text: A constitution enacted in 1889 forbids female from assuming this role, despite eight female have before. In 1932, a Korean tried to assassinate with a grenade the then-holder of this position who assumed the Chrysanthemum Throne. This position’s divinity is denied by a 1946 speech known as Humanity Declaration. For 10 points--identify this position which was “restored” by Meiji.

questions.first_sentence: This ruler stole the bride from Piso's wedding feast before he married her, allegedly, in Romulus' style.
questions.text: This ruler stole the bride from Piso's wedding feast before he married her, allegedly, in Romulus' style. Initiated by his predecessor who was also his great uncle, he concluded the restoration of Theather of Pompey. To proof Thrasyllus wrong, he crossed a pontoon bridge on his horse Inciatus. Nicknamed "little boots"--for 10 points--which Roman Emperor was the son of Gorbanicus and was known to be insane.

questions.first_sentence: In 1809, it cost lives to build a 600 miles road in this island connecting two ends of this island, Anyer and Panarukan, known as The Great Post Road.
questions.text: In 1809, it cost lives to build a 600 miles road in this island connecting two ends of this island, Anyer and Panarukan, known as The Great Post Road. Located on The Ring of Fire, this island is home to Mount Merapi where a study said its eruption buried the world largest Buddhist temple also in this island, Borobudur. Located on the east of Sumatera--for 10 points--what island hosts the capital of Indonesia, Jakarta.

questions.first_sentence: After losing all but five participating soldiers in an attack, this ruler pulled a night ambush with the help of Okubo Tadayo to survive the Battle of Mikatagahara.
questions.text: After losing all but five participating soldiers in an attack, this ruler pulled a night ambush with the help of Okubo Tadayo to survive the Battle of Mikatagahara. His father allowed him to be killed to prove his father’s allegiance to Imagawa. This ally of Oda Nobunaga defeated the forces of Ishida Mitsunari in the Battle of Sekigahara. For 10 points---name this founder of Japan's final shogunate

questions.first_sentence: This is the sometimes sophomoric but always hilarious act of pulling down the rear of one's pants and displaying one's nude buttocks to another person, often an unsuspecting stranger, sometimes from a moving vehicle.
questions.text: This is the sometimes sophomoric but always hilarious act of pulling down the rear of one's pants and displaying one's nude buttocks to another person, often an unsuspecting stranger, sometimes from a moving vehicle. Only twelve people have ever been to this location, though some people believe their visit was faked. This is both the name and setting of a movie in which Sam Rockwell's character overcomes profound existential crises by, among other things, defeating his newly discovered clone in ping-pong. The Pink Floyd album with cover art that features light refracting through a prism is called the dark side of this.

questions.first_sentence: The stability of these systems can be characterized by the ratio of two forms of pressure; that ratio is symbolized beta.
questions.text: The stability of these systems can be characterized by the ratio of two forms of pressure; that ratio is symbolized beta. The product of Boltzmann's constant, temperature, and number density gives these systems' namesake pressure. When these systems are subject to a tension force proportional to "B dot grad B," they can be compressed into "pinches," according to ideal MHD. These substances are confined at very high temperatures and densities in a torus-shaped device called a tokamak to perform nuclear fusion. Natural examples of these substances include the aurora borealis, the ionosphere, and lightning. For 10 points, name these ionized gases usually considered the fourth state of matter.

questions.first_sentence: This compound and water are produced in a process found in Brocadia and other bacteria with distinctive ladderane lipids.
questions.text: This compound and water are produced in a process found in Brocadia and other bacteria with distinctive ladderane lipids. This gas is produced in a specialized organelle with a riboplasm and paryphoplasm, which is known as the anammoxosome. Oxygen often interferes with the reduction of this element, which can be alleviated by leghemoglobin. An enzyme that reduces this compound relies on an iron molybdenum cofactor found in the legume-associating Rhizobium bacteria. Diazotrophs can aid "fixation" of this compound and convert it to ammonia. This element, phosphorus, and potassium are the major ingredients of fertilizers. For 10 points, name this gas, central to a biogeochemical cycle, which makes up the majority of the atmosphere.

questions.first_sentence: Klystrons are primarily used as sources of this phenomenon, which is used to stimulate transitions created by the Zeeman effect in electron spin resonance.
questions.text: Klystrons are primarily used as sources of this phenomenon, which is used to stimulate transitions created by the Zeeman effect in electron spin resonance. Cavity magnetrons produce this phenomenon. OH and CH radicals in molecular clouds serve as sources of this kind of radiation from space. Charles Townes invented a device which uses rotational transitions in molecules of ammonia to produce a coherent beam of this kind of radiation via stimulated emission. Molecules with a high dipole moment, such as water, are excellent absorbers of this kind of radiation, allowing this radiation to be used in dielectric heating. For 10 points--name this radiation with wavelengths between infrared and radio waves used to efficiently reheat food.

questions.first_sentence: Mutation of the HFE gene can cause this element to build up in the body.
questions.text: Mutation of the HFE gene can cause this element to build up in the body. The protein conalbumin, from egg whites, binds to this element. Regulation of this element is controlled by stem loops known as this element's namesake response element. The enzyme that converts citrate to isocitrate contains a central cluster that has four atoms of this metal. Aconitase is a member of a family of proteins named for this element and sulfur. Cytochromes and catalase contain a prosthetic group in which this metal coordinates with a tetrapyrrole ring to help bind oxygen. This element, which is transported by transferrin and ferritin, is deficient in the most common type of anemia. For 10 points, name this metal that is found in the heme group of hemoglobin.

questions.first_sentence: This male figure requires a character who has undergone 80 ordeals to undergo one more ordeal on his way home to experience the "nine nines.
questions.text: This male figure requires a character who has undergone 80 ordeals to undergo one more ordeal on his way home to experience the "nine nines." A character visits this figure's home on Vulture Peak to request his help in subduing a six-eared macaque. This figure punishes his second disciple, the Golden Cicada, with reincarnation after he sleeps during this man's sermon. A character graffitis and urinates on a bronze pillar that turns out to be this man's finger, after which this man imprisons that character, the Monkey King, under a mountain for 500 years. Near the end of a novel, this man gives scriptures to the monk Tang Sanzang, who is a reincarnation of a follower of this man. For 10 points, name this religious figure whose realm is the goal of the Journey to the West.

questions.first_sentence: NMR samples with this property have significant anisotropic effects, while in samples without this property, the anisotropies cancel out.
questions.text: NMR samples with this property have significant anisotropic effects, while in samples without this property, the anisotropies cancel out. Hermann-Mauguin notation may be used to characterize samples with this property into one of 230 space groups. Objects with this property were modeled as a network of quantum harmonic oscillators by Albert Einstein. The Laue method analyzes samples with this property which have been ground to a powder, after which their Bragg scattering is analyzed. Dislocations and vacancies are defects that may be found in materials with this property. X-ray diffraction analyzes materials with this property that possess long-range order, unlike amorphous materials. For 10 points--name these solids that form a repeating lattice structure.

questions.first_sentence: ASS syndrome is caused by an autoimmune reaction to enzymes that modify a hydroxyl group on these molecules.
questions.text: ASS syndrome is caused by an autoimmune reaction to enzymes that modify a hydroxyl group on these molecules. In bacteria, unloaded examples of these molecules can trigger the stringent response by signaling amino acid starvation. Tetracyclines prevent the binding of these molecules. A molecule of pseudouridine is found on the T-psi-C arm of these molecules. The five-prime ends of these molecules can participate in wobble pairing. Elongation factors assist in the binding of these molecules to the A site. These cloverleaf-shaped molecules are ligated with amino acids before they are transported to the ribosome. For 10 points, name these molecules whose anticodons bind to mRNAs during translation.

questions.first_sentence: "Vsye schastliviye semi poxozhi droog na drooga," so begins this famous novel by Russia's favorite author about love and marriage.
questions.text: "Vsye schastliviye semi poxozhi droog na drooga," so begins this famous novel by Russia's favorite author about love and marriage.

questions.first_sentence: An interference pattern created by the reflection of light between two surfaces is called this physicist’s “rings.”
questions.text: An interference pattern created by the reflection of light between two surfaces is called this physicist’s “rings.” His 1704 book Opticks demonstrates how color arises from the reflection of components of white light. He names a law relating the rate of (*) heat loss to the surrounding temperature, called his law of cooling. Another law named for this man is an inverse-square law describing a force between two masses; that is his law of universal gravitation. His second law states that F=ma, for 10 points, name this English scientist who names three laws of motion.

questions.first_sentence: This man argued for the annexation of West Florida when he was temporarily appointed to replace Senator Buckner Thurston.
questions.text: This man argued for the annexation of West Florida when he was temporarily appointed to replace Senator Buckner Thurston. Humphrey Marshall fought a duel with this presidential candidate, who claimed he would “rather be right than be president” in an (*) 1839 speech to the Senate. In 1824, this man was appointed as Secretary of State by John Quincy Adams after the presidential election went to a House runoff. This proponent of the American System also introduced the Compromise of 1850. For 10 points, name this Kentucky Whig who served as Speaker of the House and was nicknamed “The Great Compromiser”.

questions.first_sentence: One governor of this state gained prominence through the radio with his band Pat O’Daniel and the Hillbilly Boys.
questions.text: One governor of this state gained prominence through the radio with his band Pat O’Daniel and the Hillbilly Boys. A congressman from this state holds the record for longest tenure as Speaker of the House; that man is Sam Rayburn. One politician from this state claimed “the (*) vice presidency wasn't worth a bucket of warm piss.” Another politician from this state used his namesake treatment to round up votes as Senate Majority Leader and later began a “War on Poverty” after becoming President. For 10 points, name this home state of John Nance Garner and Lyndon Baines Johnson, with capital at Austin.

questions.first_sentence: In solid-state dye lasers, the gain medium is one of these molecules called PMMA.
questions.text: In solid-state dye lasers, the gain medium is one of these molecules called PMMA. Partially miscible solutions containing these compounds exhibit a UCST and LCST phase transition. The “electroluminescent conducting” type of these compounds are used in OLED displays. The (*) Flory-Huggins model describes them, and Ziegler-Natta catalysts aid the formation of these molecules. Thermoplastic ones are remoldable and their synthesis can be categorized as step-growth or chain-growth. For 10 points, name these compounds made of repeating units called monomers.

questions.first_sentence: Theodor, Nikolaus, and Seppi encounter this charmer who says that “man begins as dirt and departs as stench” in a novel by Mark Twain.
questions.text: Theodor, Nikolaus, and Seppi encounter this charmer who says that “man begins as dirt and departs as stench” in a novel by Mark Twain. In one work, this man puts on a show at the Variety Theater where Behemoth decapitates a man, later putting it back on due to audience demands. After journeying the Valley of Humiliation, the protagonist of (*) A Pilgrim’s Progress fights this character. This tempter finds himself on a boiling lake of lava in another epic where later on he turns into a serpent. For 10 points, name this antagonist of Paradise Lost who attempted to overthrow God.

questions.first_sentence: This quantity appears in the first row and column of the Faraday tensor.
questions.text: This quantity appears in the first row and column of the Faraday tensor. Potential energy due to the presence of this quantity is equal to one-half permittivity times the volume integral of the magnitude of this quantity squared. The Poynting vector crosses this quantity’s vector with the (*) H field, and this quantity is constant between parallel plates in a capacitor. If charges are stable, then Coulomb's law can be used to find this quantity which is measured in Newtons per coulomb. For 10 points, name this field symbolized with an E.

questions.first_sentence: This state's Governor, Jim Justice, has been known to use colorful metaphors and digs at political opponents, such as displaying a nothing burger, a mayonnaise sandwich, and a platter of bovine droppings to demonstrate his opposition to the state's proposed budget bill.
questions.text: This state's Governor, Jim Justice, has been known to use colorful metaphors and digs at political opponents, such as displaying a nothing burger, a mayonnaise sandwich, and a platter of bovine droppings to demonstrate his opposition to the state's proposed budget bill. This state was surveyed by Governor Alexander Spotswood and his knights of the Golden Horseshoe. It was the location of the Battle of Carnifex Ferry and the Battle of Philippi during the American Civil War, both of which were fought before this state seceded from its neighbor to the east in 1863. For the point, name this Appalachian state, whose capital is Charleston.

questions.first_sentence: Part of this work was adapted into a 1998 film, titled "A Soldier's Sweetheart.
questions.text: Part of this work was adapted into a 1998 film, titled "A Soldier's Sweetheart." Many characters of the collection are semi-autobiographical, paralleling the author's memoir, "If I Die in a Combat Zone, Box Me Up and Ship Me Home." In this work, the main character's experiences as a soldier in the 23rd Infantry Division are accounted in vignettes like "Sweetheart of the Song Tra Bong" and "How to Tell a True War Story." For the point, name this collection of short stories, written by Tim O'Brien.

questions.first_sentence: The Clapeyron equation is first derived by considering the total differential of this quantity.
questions.text: The Clapeyron equation is first derived by considering the total differential of this quantity. Maxwell relations are usually used to eliminate derivatives involving this quantity, since it can't be exactly measured. The inexact differential of reversible heat is converted to an exact differential in this quantity by dividing it by temperature. The derivative of this quantity with respect to time in a closed system is always greater than or equal to zero. For 10 points, name this quantity whose increase in a system is given by the Second Law.

questions.first_sentence: One writer first encountered this work while living with a woman whom he called the living embodiment of its author.
questions.text: One writer first encountered this work while living with a woman whom he called the living embodiment of its author. That writer, Henry Miller, wrote a meditation on the author titled The Time of the Assassins. Daniel Mendolsohn calls this work “a kaleidoscopic evocation of a man,” and thinks that the Foolish Virgin of this poem its most interesting aspect. In this poem, the narrator calls his ancestors “the most inept flayers of cattle and burners of grass of their age.” Later, he breaks completely with his ancestors, asserting that “it is necessary to be absolutely modern.” The poet wrote this poem in 1873 while at his mother’s farm, before his twentieth birthday. For 10 points, name this poem written by Arthur Rimbaud, which begins with the famous lines “once, if my memory serves me well.”

questions.first_sentence: The first leader of this province resigned after a scandal over loan guarantees to a private railroad company attempting to service Lac La Biche, but before a commission cleared him of any wrongdoing.
questions.text: The first leader of this province resigned after a scandal over loan guarantees to a private railroad company attempting to service Lac La Biche, but before a commission cleared him of any wrongdoing. The man who replaced him, Arthur Sifton, was brought in by the lieutenant governor of this province, George Bulyea. The Depression brought hard times to this province, leading to the election of a radio Baptist preacher who believed in the A + B Theorem or C.H. Douglas, Bill Aberhart. Much of Aberhart’s platform, such as the issuing of “prosperity certificates” and the Accurate News and Information Act, was declared unconstitutional, ending hope for a true Social Credit regime in this province. Later, the discovery of oil sands caused a massive influx of population to the province, laying the ground for decades of Progressive Conservative rule, only ended by the election of Andrea Horwath in 2015. For 10 points, name this Canadian province with a capital at Edmonton.

questions.first_sentence: The northernmost part of this region is home to the War Correspondents Memorial Arch, a memorial created by a man who went under the pen name “Gath.
questions.text: The northernmost part of this region is home to the War Correspondents Memorial Arch, a memorial created by a man who went under the pen name “Gath.” That part of this region is known as South Mountain. In a song by Eddie From Ohio, The Rocky Mountains are said to be eroding wannabes compared to this region. The “Cannonball,” one of the Appalachian Trail’s hardest sections, is located in the north of this region. This region was the location of a double murder in 1996 that Bill Bryson writes about in A Walk in the Woods. The highest point of this region is in its southern end, near Asheville. That point, Mount Mitchell, is the highpoint of North Carolina. This region encompasses two national parks, Great Smoky Mountains and Shenandoah, and features a namesake parkway. For 10 points, name this mountain range stretching from Georgia to Pennsylvania, named for the color it appears as from a distance.

questions.first_sentence: One of these concepts can be created by inserting two spheres into the title object.
questions.text: One of these concepts can be created by inserting two spheres into the title object. Ax squared plus Bx plus C is an equation for one of these items, when one of the items concerned has a steep slope. A Hyperbola is a type of, for ten points, what shapes made by passing a plane through a namesake solid whose area is given by one-third Pi r squared times height?

questions.first_sentence: These things were described by Edgar Allen Poe as possibly being nested within themselves.
questions.text: These things were described by Edgar Allen Poe as possibly being nested within themselves. Langston Hughes implored us to hold fast to these, and warned about the consequences of deferring one. William Butler Yeats implored his listener to tread softly on these, which had been spread underfoot. For the point, name these events involving rapid eye movement, which can also describe human ambitions and aspirations.

questions.first_sentence: The finale of one symphony by this composer incorporates the folk song “
questions.text: The finale of one symphony by this composer incorporates the folk song “In the Field Stood a Birch Tree” and like Beethoven, uses a “Fate” motif. Another symphony by this composer contains a horn solo that begins D C# B D C# in its Andante cantabile second movement. This composer also wrote a “Fantasy-Overture” that lacked an opus number that depicts in its introduction Friar Laurence. This composer also used Chinese Tea and Russian Trepak as part of Danse caracteristiques in the suite of a larger ballet. For 10 points, name this composer of Romeo and Juliet the Nutcracker.

questions.first_sentence: In one diary entry, this character recounts a prostitute with a “young face” who turns out to be at “fifty years old at least.”
questions.text: In one diary entry, this character recounts a prostitute with a “young face” who turns out to be at “fifty years old at least.” Another entry by this character describes how “if there was hope, it lay in the proles.” This character places a white grain of dust on the cover of his diary, which was purchased at Mr. Charrington’s shop for “two dollars fifty.” This character recognizes his diary as a “thoughtcrime” and greets from the “age of doublethink” while writing “for” and “to” O’Brien. For 10 points, name this character who writes “DOWN WITH BIG BROTHER” in his entry dated April 4th, 1984.

questions.first_sentence: A counterpart doctrine to this treaty in a neighboring country was known as the Sandomierz Consensus.
questions.text: A counterpart doctrine to this treaty in a neighboring country was known as the Sandomierz Consensus. The Landsberg Alliance was formed to uphold this treaty. Another document named after the same city as this treaty is considered one of the primary documents of the Lutheran faith. A preceding document to this treaty was named after Passau. A measure inserted into this treaty named after the brother and eventual successor of the ruler at the time exempted knights and some cities from religious uniformity, if the reformed religion had been practiced since the 1520s. FTP, name this 1555 peace enacted by Holy Roman Emperor Charles V that allowed rulers to choose either Lutheranism or Roman Catholicism as the official confession of their principality.

questions.first_sentence: In Treehouse of Horror II's "Monkey Paw" sketch, this character uses the titular entity to overthrow the alien invasion, and this characterwas decapitated in "Nightmare at Six and a Half Feet".
questions.text: In Treehouse of Horror II's "Monkey Paw" sketch, this character uses the titular entity to overthrow the alien invasion, and this characterwas decapitated in "Nightmare at Six and a Half Feet". This man rules the world in Treehouse V's "The Butterfly Effect" and in a zombie episode asks to nibble on Homer's ear. This character was the devil in "The Devil and Homer Simpson" and gives Homer the forbidden donut. In a non-Halloween episode this episode realizes that he hates Homer to whom he usually says "howdy diddly." For ten point, name this mistachiod next door neighbor of Homer Simpson who's best known for owning a leftorium and being overly religious.

questions.first_sentence: One river that runs through this polity splits into four parts, including the Pison, which covers the Havilah region, noted for its gold.
questions.text: One river that runs through this polity splits into four parts, including the Pison, which covers the Havilah region, noted for its gold. Allegedly, an angel with a flaming sword protects a tree in this polity from those who would eat its fruit. One member of this polity was expelled for eating a forbidden fruit which was supposed to make her wise "like God." That expelled member was convinced to eat the fruit by a serpant and was named Eve. For ten points, name this Biblical location where the first two people lived until the fall.

questions.first_sentence: Alberti bass involves alternating between the root note and this scale degree.
questions.text: Alberti bass involves alternating between the root note and this scale degree. Gustav Nottebohm observed that the third movement of Beethoven's Symphony of this ordinal number shares a theme with fourth movement of Mozart's fortieth symphony. On the guitar, a "power chord" consists of the root and this interval above the root. Elmer Gantry joins this profession after retiring from football, and in Great Expectations one named Jaggers sends money to Pip. questions.text: Though this modern-day nation does not have a formal constitution, one main instrument in its formation was signed in 1603 following the death of a monarch who was sometimes called “Gloriana.” Its purpose was to unify three kingdoms under a monarch who is known as both “the Fourth” and “the First." That leader survived the Gunpowder Plot and authorized a namesake translation of the Bible. James, King of Scots, and Elizabeth I were historical rulers of, for ten points, what modern day country?

questions.first_sentence: Authorship of this famous holiday poem remains in dispute, but it was first published anonymously in 1823 in the Troy, New York Sentinel.
questions.text: Authorship of this famous holiday poem remains in dispute, but it was first published anonymously in 1823 in the Troy, New York Sentinel. The man credited with writing this famous poem was a Biblical scholar, and his original usage of the word “breast of the new-fallen snow”* is usually altered to “crest” in modern readings of this poem. The title character of this poem is “dressed all in fur/From his head to his foot,” and his clothes were covered in “ashes and soot.” For 10 points, name this poem about the title character who “came down the chimney in a bound” on the title holiday eve, by Clement C. Moore.

questions.first_sentence: Members of this group formed the Grange after the Civil War, and other members of this group joined namesake “Alliances” after the Reconstruction period ended.
questions.text: Members of this group formed the Grange after the Civil War, and other members of this group joined namesake “Alliances” after the Reconstruction period ended. The Populist Party was founded to benefit members of this group, which pushed for the addition of “free silver”* to the currency as a way to alleviate deflation. Members of this group were leaders of the 1787 Shays’ Rebellion, which began when land owned by members of this group was confiscated by local courts. For 10 points, name these people who grow crops and are roughly 2 percent of America’s population today.

questions.first_sentence: This scientist worked with Tycho Brahe {BRAH-HEE} until his death in 1601, and the two men disputed over Copernican and Ptolemaic theory regarding the orbits of the planets.
questions.text: This scientist worked with Tycho Brahe {BRAH-HEE} until his death in 1601, and the two men disputed over Copernican and Ptolemaic theory regarding the orbits of the planets. This scientist devised two laws of planetary motion, one of which described planetary orbits as “elliptical,”* while the other states that “planets sweep out equal areas in equal times.” This man created a Platonic solid model of the solar system, which he detailed in his first major work Mysterium Cosmographicum {COZ-MOE-GRAFF-IH-COME}. For 10 points, name this German astronomer whose work influenced Isaac Newton’s gravitational theories.

questions.first_sentence: This number is related to Euler’s identity, and is used as a “sentinel value” in software development to show that a variable contains no useful information.
questions.text: This number is related to Euler’s identity, and is used as a “sentinel value” in software development to show that a variable contains no useful information. This number is used in programming languages to index the last or second to last item of an array, depending on whether that number was 1 or 0.* Multiplying a number by this number is equivalent to changing its sign, which is proved by using the distributive law. For 10 points, name this number, which is the additive inverse of 1.

questions.first_sentence: This non-Pacific Ocean nation’s Hebrides {HEB-RIH-DEES} islands contain the Isle of Lewis and the rugged Isle of Skye.
questions.text: This non-Pacific Ocean nation’s Hebrides {HEB-RIH-DEES} islands contain the Isle of Lewis and the rugged Isle of Skye. The River Tweed separates this country from its more populous southern neighbor, and its largest city, Glasgow, is situated on the River Clyde.* This nation’s inland freshwater lakes are referred to as “lochs” {LOCKS}, and the largest of these is Loch Lomond {LUH-MOND}. The Central Lowlands of this nation contains over half of its population, and its four largest cities. For 10 points, name this nation, the northernmost of the United Kingdom, with its capital at Edinburgh {EDD-EN-BURR-OH}.

questions.first_sentence: In Baroque music, this key is referred to as the “key of benediction,” and Johann Sebastian Bach’s Goldberg Variations have been described as “80 minutes of this key.”
questions.text: In Baroque music, this key is referred to as the “key of benediction,” and Johann Sebastian Bach’s Goldberg Variations have been described as “80 minutes of this key.” The music to The Star-Spangled Banner was originally written in this key, but is commonly sung in an A-flat or B-flat major* today. This key’s relative minor is E-minor, and its key signature is F# {F-Sharp}. For 10 points, name this musical key, which forms the home key of Mozart’s Eine Kleine Nachtmusik {INE-KLY-NUH-NAHKT-MUSIC}, and whose dominant key is D-major.

questions.first_sentence: Ovid’s epic poem Fasti {FAH-SHTEE} contains an extensive history of this mythological character, including an account in which he came back from the dead to haunt Faustulus {FOW-STUH-LUSS}, who raised him and his twin brother.
questions.text: Ovid’s epic poem Fasti {FAH-SHTEE} contains an extensive history of this mythological character, including an account in which he came back from the dead to haunt Faustulus {FOW-STUH-LUSS}, who raised him and his twin brother. This man, along with his twin, had been suckled by a she-wolf* in a cave named Lupercal before being raised by Faustulus. This man disputed with his brother over which hill to build the city of Rome, and was killed either by his brother or a supporter of his brother. For 10 points, name this mythological man whose twin brother Romulus was the founder of Rome.

questions.first_sentence: . This novel opens with the protagonist in a hut, waiting for a battle, and reminiscing about his decision to join the army.
questions.text: . This novel opens with the protagonist in a hut, waiting for a battle, and reminiscing about his decision to join the army. When that battle comes, that protagonist in this novel abandons the battlefield in fear, only to return to a crowd of wounded men in the aftermath.* He is hit over the head by a fellow retreating soldier, after seeing Jim Conklin die in front of him. When this protagonist finally enters battle with his regiment, he takes the role of flag bearer after the original man is killed. For 10 points, name this novel about Henry Fleming’s attempt to gain the title “wound,” by Stephen Crane.

questions.first_sentence: This idea was first implemented by the French in 1784, after a satirical article by Benjamin Franklin.
questions.text: This idea was first implemented by the French in 1784, after a satirical article by Benjamin Franklin. America first adopted this idea during World War I, and in World War II, it was mandated to occur year-round. President Lyndon Johnson signed the Uniform Time Act of 1966 to make this nationwide,* unless a state opted out. Alaska, Hawaii, and Arizona have never had this, and most of Indiana did not use this until a 2005 state law mandated its use. For 10 points, name this concept, in which Americans move their clocks forward in March and back in November.

questions.first_sentence: This organ can be affected by eczema {EK-SUH-MUH} and psoriasis {SORE-EYE-AH-SUSS} and is made up of sebaceous glands.
questions.text: This organ can be affected by eczema {EK-SUH-MUH} and psoriasis {SORE-EYE-AH-SUSS} and is made up of sebaceous glands. Those glands from this organ secrete a waxy, oily substance that lubricates and waterproofs the body. This organ ranges in thickness* from 0.5 mm {millimeters} around the eyes, to over 4 mm in the palms and the soles of the feet. Those aforementioned areas are also the only parts of this organ that do not contain sebaceous glands. For 10 points, name this largest organ of the body, which is made up of the dermis and the epidermis.

questions.first_sentence: The MKS unit of magnetomotive force is theproduct of the unit named for this person times thenumber of turns.
questions.text: The MKS unit of magnetomotive force is theproduct of the unit named for this person times thenumber of turns. One law named after this personis a consequence of the Lorentz force and gives theforce between two wires that are carrying current.Another law named for this person can be stated as“the vacuum permeability times current densityequals the curl of the magnetic field” and is one ofMaxwell’s equations, which Maxwell amended byincorporating the displacement current. Identifythis person whose namesake unit equals acoulomb[koo-loam]per second and is used to measurecurrent.

questions.first_sentence: The Deccan Traps in India are primarily formedfrom multiple layers of this rock.
questions.text: The Deccan Traps in India are primarily formedfrom multiple layers of this rock. Early geologistsstudying continental drift used the term“sima”[SIM-uh]for crust made primarily of this rock, andtheorized that a layer of it may have extendedunderneath continents. As this rock’s lava cools, itmay form columns such as those in Devils PostpileNational Monument in California.A’a [ah-AH]andpahoehoe [puh-HOY-hoy]are terms for flows of lavamade of this typically dark rock, which also existsat mid-ocean ridges in a form nicknamed “MORB”.Name this extrusive igneous rock, the primaryconstituent of oceanic crust

questions.first_sentence: In earlier versions of FORTRAN this data structure could only be allocated statically so the largest possible size had to be used.
questions.text: In earlier versions of FORTRAN this data structure could only be allocated statically so the largest possible size had to be used. It's not a hash table, but Bloom filters use this as their underlying data structure, as do heaps. Randomly accessing an element takes only constant time, and these data structures are cache friendly, unlike linked lists. For 10 points name this data structure which is a collection of elements stored in a block of contiguous memory.

questions.first_sentence: A member of this group released the cookbook Barbeque'n with Bobby and was forcibly chained to a chair and gagged while trying to defend himself in court.
questions.text: A member of this group released the cookbook Barbeque'n with Bobby and was forcibly chained to a chair and gagged while trying to defend himself in court. A member of this group formed a non-aggression pact between gangs in Chicago in 1969. A Member of this group fled to Algeria in 1968. This group enacted the Free Breakfast for Children Program for impoverished youth. A member of this party, Fred Hampton was killed in his sleep by police. Bobby Seale and Huey Newton founded, for 10 points, what black nationalist party that operated in the late 1960s?

questions.first_sentence: A play by this author is named for a train that goes from New Orleans to Los Angeles and is subtitled "A Novel in Dramatic Form".
questions.text: A play by this author is named for a train that goes from New Orleans to Los Angeles and is subtitled "A Novel in Dramatic Form". In another work by this author, the protagonists eat a meal of canned pears and peaches in a bunker, but fail to find weapons. In that work, a man lights an adversary on fire with a flare but is unable to overcome an arrow wound from the fighting. In another work, this author created a group who robs a ferry on the Colorado River and massacres their (*) Yuma allies. In that novel, a man buys a string of ears from his gang after its original owner is hanged in Los Angeles. This author wrote about a man who travels with his son through a dystopian wasteland in The Road. For ten points, name this American author who wrote about the Kid's life with the Glanton gang in his novel Blood Meridian.

questions.first_sentence: his event resulted in a nearly 30% fall in the income of taxi drivers.
questions.text: his event resulted in a nearly 30% fall in the income of taxi drivers. As a result of fewer cars on the roads, people could breathe easy in the area this event took place in for the first time in months, as PM2.5 levels finally fell within the recommended safety limits of the World Health Organization. This event polarized the society it took place in, resulting in a flurry of unfriendings on Facebook and a yellow vs. blue war. The BBC provoked controversy when it filmed the hiring of unsuspecting people in order to protest this event, which a Legislative Council member also alleged that threats from (*) triads were used to disperse. The government’s strict stance against this event was likely in order to suppress similar movements in other regions denied the right this event was demanding, and it deleted any internet posts with words like ‘barricade’ and the name of this protest in it. For ten points, name these protests by university students demanding political reform in Central, Hong Kong.

questions.first_sentence: Six holes were formed in this material by Saburo Murakami in the First Gutai Exhibition, though he is more famous for performance art pieces in which he hurled himself at this material.
questions.text: Six holes were formed in this material by Saburo Murakami in the First Gutai Exhibition, though he is more famous for performance art pieces in which he hurled himself at this material. At the 1975 exhibition Women Here and Now, Carolee Schneemann extracted an object made of this material from her vagina while standing on a table. A work created with this material features a floating man with an abnormally large penis and a woman giving birth to babies that fall onto the ground. That work’s title refers to Mitchell’s Gone with the Wind and is by (*) Kara Walker. The Hotel Regina saw this material mounted on burlap in a site-specific installation titled The Swimming Pool. One work made from this material is composed of multicolored blocks against an orange background, The Snail, is part of a series called Jazz. For 10 points, name this material that Henri Matisse used in his cut-outs.

questions.first_sentence: This author wrote about “the quivering that enraptures us, and comforts, and helps” in describing the aftermath of the death of Linos.
questions.text: This author wrote about “the quivering that enraptures us, and comforts, and helps” in describing the aftermath of the death of Linos. This author wrote another poem whose title object guides a smile “through the placid hips and thighs / to that dark center where procreation flared” and which is “still suffused with brilliance from inside, like a lamp.” That poem by this author concludes “you must change your life.” This poet asked, “Who, if I cried out, would hear me among the angelic orders?” in the first poem of a collection titled after an Italian castle. For 10 points, name this early 20th century German poet of “Archaic Torso of Apollo” and The Duino Elegies.

questions.first_sentence: Michel Foucault coined the term “noso-politics” in an essay which discusses the integration of public and private administration of this profession during the 18th century.
questions.text: Michel Foucault coined the term “noso-politics” in an essay which discusses the integration of public and private administration of this profession during the 18th century. The difficulty Hmong refugees have in adjusting to the practice of this profession in the United States is the subject of Anne Fadiman’s book The Spirit Catches You and You Fall Down. This is the profession of the author of An Anthropologist on Mars and The Man Who Mistook His Wife for a Hat, Oliver Sacks. The largest quango in the UK works in this profession and administers the NHS. For 10 points, name this profession, whose practitioners take the Hippocratic Oath to “do no harm.”

questions.first_sentence: This story’s protagonist pictures “a young man under a dripping tree” and realizes he is imagining shades of the afterlife.
questions.text: This story’s protagonist pictures “a young man under a dripping tree” and realizes he is imagining shades of the afterlife. Its protagonist admits he is “sick of his own country” after Molly Ivors invites him to go to the Aran Islands. In this story, Mr. Browne attempts to calm a drunk Freddy Mallins at a dinner party hosted by the elderly sisters Julia and Kate Morkan. In this story, the tenor Bartell D’Arcy sings “The Lass of Aughrim,” which reminds Gretta of her childhood love Michael Furey. At the end of this story, snow falls softly “all over Ireland” as Gabriel Conroy stares out the window. For 10 points, name this last story of James Joyce’s collection Dubliners.

questions.first_sentence: People referred to using this term carry long staffs and use Martini-Henry rifles to shoot at Africans in Heart of Darkness, and the protagonist of Slaughterhouse 5 has this surname.
questions.text: People referred to using this term carry long staffs and use Martini-Henry rifles to shoot at Africans in Heart of Darkness, and the protagonist of Slaughterhouse 5 has this surname. A group of these people who meet in an inn include a miller, a knight, and the wife of Bath and tell each other The Canterbury Tales. For ten points, Paul Bunyan authored the “Progress” of what people?

questions.first_sentence: In an essay, this author discusses the use of incident and tone in order to achieve a desired "effect" in writing a literary work, and details how he used these concepts in writing his most famous poem.
questions.text: In an essay, this author discusses the use of incident and tone in order to achieve a desired "effect" in writing a literary work, and details how he used these concepts in writing his most famous poem. In a poem by this author, a woman is described with having "hyacinth hair" and a beauty "like those Nicean barks of yore." In "The Philosophy of Composition," this author discusses how a "tapping" at a chamber door leads to the narrator's introduction of Lenore in one of his poems. For 10 points, name this author of "To Helen," who also wrote about a bird that repeatedly cries "Nevermore" in "The Raven."

questions.first_sentence: This number is one hundred and fifty less than the number of horses that rode into the Valley of Death.
questions.text: This number is one hundred and fifty less than the number of horses that rode into the Valley of Death. This number is one hundred and fifty more than the number of Spartans at Thermopylae. This number is thirty more than a number often associatd with cannabis. For ten points, what number is equivalent to nine times fifty?

questions.first_sentence: This woman's youngest and longest-lived daughter was named Chloris by some accounts.
questions.text: This woman's youngest and longest-lived daughter was named Chloris by some accounts. She was known for inheriting the "mad pride" of her father and marrying a son of Antiope who moved stones with his song. That man committed suicide after the death of his children by this woman. For 10 points, name this daughter of Tantalus who turned into stone after the killing of her children by Apollo and Artemis.

questions.first_sentence: In 2006, Markus Allback scored the 2000th goal in this competition.
questions.text: In 2006, Markus Allback scored the 2000th goal in this competition. A dog by the name of Pickles was notably credited with discovering the championship trophy for this event when it went missing in 1966. This event was canceled during the World Wars, and in 2010 this event was held in Africa for the first time. For 10 points, name this tournament held every four years, that will be contested in Russia in 2018.

questions.first_sentence: Felix Mendelssohn sightread a part for a piece of this type for its 1842 premiere, and suggested the addition of a second trio for its third movement Scherzo.
questions.text: Felix Mendelssohn sightread a part for a piece of this type for its 1842 premiere, and suggested the addition of a second trio for its third movement Scherzo. Another piece of this type begins with an F minor theme played in unison, and was originally conceived as a string quintet, then a sonata for two pianos, by its composer Johannes Brahms. Robert Schumann's E Flat Major piece of this type established it as a standard chamber music genre, but an earlier piece of this type contains a theme and variations on the lieder "Die Forelle." That piece of this type is nicknamed "Trout." For 10 points, name this genre of music written for a string quartet plus piano.

questions.first_sentence: One of this composer's pieces ends with an extremely brief Presto finale and led Robert Schumann to comment that it ended "as it began, with a riddle, like a Sphinx – with a mocking smile on its lips.
questions.text: One of this composer's pieces ends with an extremely brief Presto finale and led Robert Schumann to comment that it ended "as it began, with a riddle, like a Sphinx – with a mocking smile on its lips." That piece by this composer is most famous for a third movement that contains a D-flat major trio section in between the outer B flat minor portions that nickname the piece. This composer wrote pieces nicknamed "Military" and "Heroic" in the form of a dance named after his home country. For 10 points, name this composer of a famous Funeral March for piano, as well as many mazurkas and polonaises.

questions.first_sentence: According to Pliny the Elder, the poet Aristeas had a soul which came out of his mouth in the shape of one of these animals.
questions.text: According to Pliny the Elder, the poet Aristeas had a soul which came out of his mouth in the shape of one of these animals. The name of the mythical Welsh king Bran the Blessed, translated into English, refers to this animal. A stranger who is imprisoned next to two bonfires reveals his identity by talking about two of these animals flying over the earth. Those two examples of these animals are described as eating corpses and drinking blood in a twelfth-century poem, and they are often seen whispering secrets to Odin. For 10 points, name these black-feathered birds, one of whom sat upon a "pallid bust of Pallas" in a poem by Edgar Allen Poe.

questions.first_sentence: This composer was given a theme called "Chorale St. Antoni" by the archivist of the Vienna Musikverein, which could have been written by Ignaz Pleyel.
questions.text: This composer was given a theme called "Chorale St. Antoni" by the archivist of the Vienna Musikverein, which could have been written by Ignaz Pleyel. While summering in Tutzing, this composer turned that theme into "Variationen über ein Thema von Haydn", with whom the theme is traditionally associated. Although he thought it was a traditional Magyar melody, he incorporated a theme by Béla Kéler into one of his Hungarian Dances. Popularized by Clara Schumann, for ten points, name this German-Austrian composer of Academic Festival Overture and a German Requiem.

questions.first_sentence: One of these creatures is first slain by the player at the Western Watchtower.
questions.text: One of these creatures is first slain by the player at the Western Watchtower. After that battle, the player absorbs the spirit of Milmunir, one of these creatures, and gains the ability to use shouts. Another one of these creatures prevents Ulfric Stormcloak’s execution at Helgen. That monster of this type, Alduin, serves as the “main antagonist” of the game it is found in. For 10 points, name this type of monster that has “Blood”, “Frost”, and “Serpentine” varieties, from which the protagonist is “born” in Skyrim.

questions.first_sentence: This composer's Opus 10 is made up of 6 flute concertii. Another set of concertii written by this composer in his Opus 4 was dedicated to nobleman Victor Delfin and is known as La stravaganza.
questions.text: This composer's Opus 10 is made up of 6 flute concertii. Another set of concertii written by this composer in his Opus 4 was dedicated to nobleman Victor Delfin and is known as La stravaganza. A more famous set of violin concertii by this composer is a concerto for Four Violins included in his L'Estro Armenico. For 10 points, name this Italian composer who also included a set of violin concertii in the Contest Between Harmony and Invention included in the Four Seasons.

questions.first_sentence: The first plague epidemic in the continental U.S. was located in this city.
questions.text: The first plague epidemic in the continental U.S. was located in this city. In 1851, the Committee of Vigilance was formed in this city in response to rapid population growth. It was the location of the Six Gallery reading, and the (*) United Nations charter was also signed in this city. The White Night Riots began after George Moscone and Harvey Milk were assassinated in this city in 1978. For 10 points, name this Northern California city that was the site of a 1906 earthquake.

questions.first_sentence: The first plague epidemic in the continental U.S. was located in this city.
questions.text: The first plague epidemic in the continental U.S. was located in this city. In 1851, the Committee of Vigilance was formed in this city in response to rapid population growth. It was the location of the Six Gallery reading, and the (*) United Nations charter was also signed in this city. The White Night Riots began after George Moscone and Harvey Milk were assassinated in this city in 1978. For 10 points, name this Northern California city that was the site of a 1906 earthquake.

questions.first_sentence: 2. In this novel, a ‘snake-like’ machine replaces poisoned blood when the protagonist’s wife attempts to commit suicide.
questions.text: 2. In this novel, a ‘snake-like’ machine replaces poisoned blood when the protagonist’s wife attempts to commit suicide. Another character, (*) Faber, helps the protagonist escape from the Mechanical Hound. For ten points, Guy Montag was featured in what book written by Ray Bradbury?ANSWER: Fahrenheit 451

questions.first_sentence: This poet temporarily married Erika Mann, daughter of author Thomas Mann, so that she could gain British citizenship and flee Nazi Germany.
questions.text: This poet temporarily married Erika Mann, daughter of author Thomas Mann, so that she could gain British citizenship and flee Nazi Germany. He claimed that “soul and body have no bounds” in his love poem “Lullaby”. This man wrote about the end “of a low dishonest decade” as he sat “in one of the dives on (*) Fifty-second Street.” A speaker in one of this man’s poems despairs that “nothing now can ever come to any good” and “stop all the clocks” following the death of a lover. For ten points, name this poet of “Musée des Beaux Arts”, “September 1, 1939”, and “Funeral Blues.”

questions.first_sentence: A religious leader based in this country created the Final Testament, a translation of the Qur’an, and claimed to have found a code in the Qur’an based on the number 19.
questions.text: A religious leader based in this country created the Final Testament, a translation of the Qur’an, and claimed to have found a code in the Qur’an based on the number 19. That religious leader based in this country was Rashad Khalifa, the founder of United Submitters International, a Qur’anist movement. During a pilgrimage to Mecca, a leader from this country took the name el-Hajj Malik el-Shabazz, and wrote a letter describing pilgrims “of all colors, from blue-eyed blondes to black-skinned Africans,” which state that “[This country] needs to understand Islam, because this is the one religion that erases from its society the race problem.” For 10 points, name this country where Noble Drew Ali founded the Moorish Science Temple and Wallace Fard Muhammad founded the Nation of Islam.

questions.first_sentence: During a massacre of these people, the Marquis of Pianesse supposedly sent 10,000 soldiers to attack the village of Rorà after a string of victories by its defender Joshua Janavel.
questions.text: During a massacre of these people, the Marquis of Pianesse supposedly sent 10,000 soldiers to attack the village of Rorà after a string of victories by its defender Joshua Janavel. The pastor Henri Arnaud led these people during the glorieuse rentrée, or “glorious return” to their homeland. This movement’s views are summarized in a poem called the “Noble Lesson,” which notes that “there are already a thousand and one hundred years fully accomplished” while discussing the imminent end of the world. Charles Emmanuel II’s massacre of this religious movement’s members during the Piedmont Easter inspired John Milton to write his sonnet “On the Late Massacre in Piedmont.” This religious movement originally centered on a merchant who gave away his wealth, and his followers, the “Poor Men of Lyons.” For 10 points, name this Christian movement founded during the 12th century by Peter Waldo.

questions.first_sentence: On this island, families of Chinese miners were suffocated to death after they took refuge in the Ghost Cave during a rebellion led by Liu Shan Bang.
questions.text: On this island, families of Chinese miners were suffocated to death after they took refuge in the Ghost Cave during a rebellion led by Liu Shan Bang. On this island, a federation of mining associations called kongsi was founded by Luo Fangbo, the first president of the Lanfang Republic. A rebellion against a British ruler on this island, based in a hill fortress on Bukit Sadok, was led by Rentap, a warchief of the Iban people. A monarch gained power on this island after he assisted Pengiran Muda Hassan in putting down a rebellion, after which Omar Ali Saifuddin II ceded territory to him. That monarch was a British adventurer named James Brooke, who was the first White Rajah of Sarawak. For 10 points, name this island where the British established a protectorate over the Sultanate of Brunei.

questions.first_sentence: During this event, a woman was hit with a baton for complaining that her handcuffs were too tight, after which she told bystanders, “Why don’t you guys do something?
questions.text: During this event, a woman was hit with a baton for complaining that her handcuffs were too tight, after which she told bystanders, “Why don’t you guys do something?” That woman may have been Stormé DeLarverie. Participants in this event sang to the tone of “Ta-ra-ra Boom-de-ay” and formed impromptu kick lines. A Mattachine Society newsletter described this event as “the hairpin drop heard around the world.” For 10 points, name these riots caused by a police raid on a namesake Greenwich Village bar by members of the LGBT community.

questions.first_sentence: John Boyndell wrote to Sir Joshua Reynolds that this painting was “the greatest effort of art since the Sistine Chapel and the stanze of Raphael”.
questions.text: John Boyndell wrote to Sir Joshua Reynolds that this painting was “the greatest effort of art since the Sistine Chapel and the stanze of Raphael”. At the right of this painting, a man in red grasps the bridge of his nose as he holds his other arm upward, facing away from the central figure. That central figure’s thigh is being grasped by a man to his right in orange, Crito. A young man in red to the left looks away as he hands the central figure a cup. For 10 points, name this Jacques-Louis David painting that depicts the execution of an ancient Athenian philosopher.

questions.first_sentence: One ruler of this polity was said to have drunk himself to death after he heard that he had won the Lanean festival for his play The Ransom of Hector; that ruler was Dionysius the Elder.
questions.text: One ruler of this polity was said to have drunk himself to death after he heard that he had won the Lanean festival for his play The Ransom of Hector; that ruler was Dionysius the Elder. During its annual festival to Athens, the forces of Marcus Cladius Marcellus infiltrated this city. The Spartan general Gylippus was sent to aid this city against the Sicilian Expedition. For 10 points, name this city that was once home to Archimedes.

questions.first_sentence: In this painting, a long, right-facing spear is mounted on the back wall, and a corner of a window is visible in the upper left, behind the second of two archways.
questions.text: In this painting, a long, right-facing spear is mounted on the back wall, and a corner of a window is visible in the upper left, behind the second of two archways. A boy looks at the central scene of this painting, while being held by a woman in black. Another woman in this painting wears a green headband and leans her head on the shoulder of a woman in brown. One of the title figures of this painting wears a white cape and holds a spear with one hand as he reaches towards his sword-holding father with the other. For 10 points, name this Jacque-Louis David painting that shows three Roman brothers preparing to fight the Curiatii.

questions.first_sentence: To encourage debate about policy, one leader of this political party set up the Wolf Tone directories.
questions.text: To encourage debate about policy, one leader of this political party set up the Wolf Tone directories. In 1970, this party split into two opposing factions, Gardiner Place and Kevin Street. This party was founded by Arthur Griffith. A faction of this party split off to form Fianna Fáil; that faction was led by Eamon de Valera. For 10 points, name this Irish republican party once linked to the IRA.

questions.first_sentence: A pair of scissors sticks out of a basket filled with fabric at the center of this painting.
questions.text: A pair of scissors sticks out of a basket filled with fabric at the center of this painting. A servant covers her head with a blue shawl at the far left of this painting. The words “DEA ROMA” appear on the pedestal of a statue in this painting, behind a man who holds an edict ordering an execution. For 10 points, name this Jacques-Louis David painting, which shows men holding stretchers that bear the bodies of the sons of a Roman leader.

questions.first_sentence: In an interview, Steve Pieczenik claimed that this man had to be sacrificed to maintain the country he led.
questions.text: In an interview, Steve Pieczenik claimed that this man had to be sacrificed to maintain the country he led. Romano Prodi supposedly conducted a séance and used an Ouija board to discover the location of this man. For 10 points, Mino Pecorelli wrote that the “logic of Yalta” inspired the kidnapping of what Italian prime minister by the Red Brigades?

questions.first_sentence: During this rebellion, Yao Zhifu committed suicide with the female rebel Wang Cong’er.
questions.text: During this rebellion, Yao Zhifu committed suicide with the female rebel Wang Cong’er. Wang Lung led a predecessor to this rebellion twenty years before it. The general Fukung’an was sent to suppress this rebellion, and the corrupt courtier Heshen was put in charge of the war effort. Participants in this rebellion believed in the imminent arrival of Maitreya, the future Buddha. For 10 points, name this rebellion against the Qing Dynasty named after a flower.

questions.first_sentence: A political cartoon from this event depicts a man in a red coat dragging out its target from underneath a bed.
questions.text: A political cartoon from this event depicts a man in a red coat dragging out its target from underneath a bed. That target of this event had previously ordered the boarding of the Purpoise before he arrived at the colony at which it took place. This event was triggered by a failed attempt to arrest John Macarthur. For 10 points, name this rebellion that deposed William Bligh as governor of New South Wales, named after a type of alcohol.

questions.first_sentence: Dissidents of this leader’s regime hijacked the Santa Maria cruise liner in Operation Dulcinea.
questions.text: Dissidents of this leader’s regime hijacked the Santa Maria cruise liner in Operation Dulcinea. Many political prisoners died in the Tarrafal prison camp established by this leader’s regime. Humbert Delgado was assassinated by this leader’s PIDE secret police. For 10 points, name this Portugese leader who established the Estado Novo regime.

questions.first_sentence: This thing is referred to as Tayyab as the first of the Six Kalimas.
questions.text: This thing is referred to as Tayyab as the first of the Six Kalimas. In the Hadith of Gabriel, this thing is mentioned first when Gabriel asks Muhammad to describe Islam. A variation of this thing that includes the phrase “Ali is the wali of God” is used by the Shia. Reciting this statement is the sole requirement of converting to Islam. For 10 points, name this Islamic declaration of faith.

questions.first_sentence: In 1986, Carl Rose wrote an article about a positive variant of this concept.
questions.text: In 1986, Carl Rose wrote an article about a positive variant of this concept. Dawn Chatty has argued that Middle Eastern governments used this concept to justify pushing the Bedouins to give up nomadic life. A work titled after this concept argues that “conscience is self-eliminating” and that the welfare state makes overbreeding a public concern. For 10 points, Garrett Hardin wrote an article about what situation in which people who make individually rational economic decisions deplete a shared resource?

questions.first_sentence: In Judaism, the first meal that follows one of these events is known as Seudat Havara’ah.
questions.text: In Judaism, the first meal that follows one of these events is known as Seudat Havara’ah. Koliva is a dish of boiled wheat that is served during these events in Eastern Orthodox tradition. In Hinduism, balls of rice and sesame called pindas are offered during these events. In Mormon culture, a popular casserole of potatoes and cream sauce topped with cheese is named after these events. In Japanese culture, these events involve placing two (*) chopsticks upright in a bowl of rice, and it is considered taboo to pass food between two pairs of chopsticks because it resembles a ritual from these events. For 10 points, a prion disease known as kuru was spread among the Fore people of Papua New Guinea because of their ritual cannibalism of the deceased during what events?

questions.first_sentence: In reference to a prophecy spoken by this man, Rabbi Akiva gave a Messianic claimant the name Bar Kokhba.
questions.text: In reference to a prophecy spoken by this man, Rabbi Akiva gave a Messianic claimant the name Bar Kokhba. That prophecy assets that “a star shall come out of Jacob, and a scepter shall rise out of Israel; it shall crush the forehead of Moab and break down all the sons of Sheth.” According to the Talmud, this man told a king to set up tents filled with harlots to make Israelites worship the idol Baal-peor. After this man does not see an (*) angel blocking him on a road, he hits the animal that he is riding on three times. Balak, the king of Moab, becomes increasing frustrated at this man when he repeatedly blesses the Israelites that he was asked to curse. For 10 points, name this man who appears in the Book of Numbers and is chastised by his own donkey.

questions.first_sentence: The Qayyúm’-i-Asmá’ was a commentary on a surah named after this man, which was one of the first writings of the Báb.
questions.text: The Qayyúm’-i-Asmá’ was a commentary on a surah named after this man, which was one of the first writings of the Báb. The surah named after this man begins by noting that it is “the most beautiful of stories.” A husband knew that his wife was lying about this man’s intentions when he saw that she had torn this man’s shirt from behind while trying to seduce this man. After some women see this man, they cut their hands with knives out of amazement and call him an angel. This man had a vision of the sun, the moon, and (*) eleven stars bowing to him, and he interpreted a king’s dream of seven fat cattle being devoured by seven lean cattle. For 10 points, name this Islamic prophet and son of Yaqub who was sold into slavery in Egypt.

questions.first_sentence: This religious community was studied by Jacques Faitlovitch, who established a school for members of this community and is known as their “father.
questions.text: This religious community was studied by Jacques Faitlovitch, who established a school for members of this community and is known as their “father.” This community celebrates a holiday with a name meaning “prostration,” which once involved ascending mountains to pray and hear scriptures. Religious leaders of this community are called kes. They aren’t blacksmiths, but they were often subjected to accusations of having evil eye powers called (*) buda. Sometimes known by the derogatory term falasha, members of this community were deemed authentic members of a certain religion by Ovadia Yosef in 1973, and by Shlomo Goren in 1975. For 10 points, Operation Solomon saw what religious community airlifted to Israel from its African country of origin?

questions.first_sentence: In a passage in this Biblical book, a man declares, “Blessed is the Lord God of Israel, for he has visited and redeemed his people and has raised up a horn of salvation for us.”
questions.text: In a passage in this Biblical book, a man declares, “Blessed is the Lord God of Israel, for he has visited and redeemed his people and has raised up a horn of salvation for us.” That passage, which also describes how “the sunrise shall visit us from on high,” is recited during Lauds and is known as the Benedictus. In another passage in this book, a woman declares, “My soul (*) magnifies the Lord” while visiting her pregnant cousin, whose son leaps for joy in her womb. In this book, a man is struck mute after he does not believe Gabriel’s news that he will have a son; that man is Zechariah, whose wife is named Elizabeth. For 10 points, name this gospel, whose first chapter describes the Nativity of John the Baptist, unlike the Gospels of Mark, Matthew, and John.

questions.first_sentence: In one of this man’s poems, the narrator commands Ramon Fernandez to tell him what he knows about a woman who “sang beyond the genius of the sea.
questions.text: In one of this man’s poems, the narrator commands Ramon Fernandez to tell him what he knows about a woman who “sang beyond the genius of the sea. Another of this man’s poems depicts Crispin’s journey from Bordeaux to North Carolina. This poet of “The Idea of Order at Key West” included the poem “The Comedian as the Letter C” in his collection (*) Harmonium, along with a poem that begins “Call the roller of big cigars.” For ten points, name this Modernist American poet of “The Emperor of Ice Cream,” who also described the title avian as “the only moving thing” among twenty snowy mountains in Thirteen Ways of Looking at a Blackbird.

questions.first_sentence: One of this author’s works concerns a “ten-centavo piece” that causes an obsession in any entity that sees it; that story, which is not by Paulo Coelho, is called “The Zahir.”
questions.text: One of this author’s works concerns a “ten-centavo piece” that causes an obsession in any entity that sees it; that story, which is not by Paulo Coelho, is called “The Zahir.” In another story by this author, an MI5 agent named Richard Madden pursues a spy for the German empire. That spy murders (*) Stephen Albert in cold blood after he had solved two mysteries in Ts'ui Pen’s novel. A novel by this author describes adjacent hexagonal rooms which together contain every book in existence. For ten points, name this Argentinian author of The Garden of Forking Paths and The Library of Babel.

questions.first_sentence: In one poem by this author, the narrator professes, “I am weary with contending!”
questions.text: In one poem by this author, the narrator professes, “I am weary with contending!” The title character of a novel by this author coaxes a girl to sit with his friend Melina at a pub after the doctor says girls don’t find him attractive. The title character of another novel by this man receives a duodecimo copy of Homer for his birthday and had previously escaped a relationship with (*) Leonora.
