This author of two poems named “Wandering Hillsong” describes a character who travels back to Wahlheim before a love triangle involving Albert and Lotte causes him to kill himself. For ten points, name this key figure in the Sturm und Drang movement, whose novel The Sorrows of Young Werther led to a wave of copycat suicides across Europe.

questions.first_sentence: In this election year, George Romney withdrew from Republican primaries following comments that he was “brainwashed,” and supporters of Eugene McCarthy went “clean for Gene” during the New Hampshire primary.
questions.text: In this election year, George Romney withdrew from Republican primaries following comments that he was “brainwashed,” and supporters of Eugene McCarthy went “clean for Gene” during the New Hampshire primary. That year saw vice presidential nominee Curtis LeMay earn controversy for supporting the potential use of tactical nuclear weapons, and Richard (*) Daley was criticized by Abe Richoff for the use of “gestapo tactics” at the Democratic National Convention. George Wallace ran on the third-party American Independent ticket in this year. For ten points, name this election year where Richard Nixon won his first term as president.

questions.first_sentence: The Landau-Ramanujan constant is related to the number of integers which can be expressed as the sum of two of these numbers.
questions.text: The Landau-Ramanujan constant is related to the number of integers which can be expressed as the sum of two of these numbers. A generalization of a problem involving sums of these numbers is known as Waring's problem, and the Trivial Inequality implies that all of these numbers are nonnegative. Lagrange proved that any positive integer can be written as the sum of (*) four of these numbers. These numbers are the only ones to have an odd number of factors. One of these modulo a number is known as a quadratic residue, and consecutive triangular numbers sum up to one of these numbers. The sum of the first n odd numbers is the nth one of these numbers. For ten points, name these numbers, which equal an integer times itself.

questions.first_sentence: 2) This poet described summer as the season where “first Sol doth in crabbed Cancer shine” in one of her four quaternions.
questions.text: 2) This poet described summer as the season where “first Sol doth in crabbed Cancer shine” in one of her four quaternions. In one poem, this poet “wakened was with thundering noise and piteous shrieks of dreadful voice” and in another she calls her work “thou ill formed offspring of my feeble brain.” This author of (*) “The Author to Her Book” described her marriage by saying “if ever two were one, then surely we” in “To My Dear and Loving Husband.” For 10 points, name this colonial Puritan poet who wrote “Verses Upon the Burning of Our House” and The Tenth Muse Lately Sprung Up in America.

questions.first_sentence: The Cohen-Kung theorem states that a one of these constructs is always unbounded.
questions.text: The Cohen-Kung theorem states that a one of these constructs is always unbounded. That entity is Langton's Ant and is one of these constructs on a two dimensional grid. These constructs are equivalent to pushdown automata with two stacks. These entities can interpret all recursively enumerable languages, which are type-0 grammars on the Chomsky hierarchy. The (*) busy beaver function is an uncomputable function about these entities. The creator of these entities demonstrated their equivalence to lambda calculus in a thesis with Alonzo Church. These devices consist of a set of instructions to manipulate ones and zeros on an infinite tape. For ten points, name this model of computation named after a British computer science.

questions.first_sentence: Trioxane is a trimer of the simplest one of these compounds.
questions.text: Trioxane is a trimer of the simplest one of these compounds. That compound can polymerize with phenol to form the synthetic plastic Bakelite. Another of these compounds is a tautomer of vinyl alcohol and can be produced by oxidizing ethylene in the Wacker process. The Cannizzaro reaction converts these compounds into carboxylic acid salts and alcohols. When reacted with a (*) silver nitrate and ammonia solution, this compound can form a "silver mirror" in Tollens' test. When open-chained, these compounds are named with the suffix "-al." For ten points, name these compounds which terminate in a carbon bonded to an oxygen and a hydrogen, whose simplest member has formula CH2O.

questions.first_sentence: The "spin-transfer" type of this quantity can be used to change the polarization of a thin layer of magnetic material.
questions.text: The "spin-transfer" type of this quantity can be used to change the polarization of a thin layer of magnetic material. This quantity governs a device in which this quantity is equal to negative kappa times theta, and Poinsot's construction can be used to predict solutions to an equation which relates this quantity to omega and the inertia matrix. For a magnetic (*) dipole in a magnetic field, this quantity is equal to the cross product of the dipole moment and the electric field. This quantity can be computed as the derivative of angular momentum or the cross product of force and the lever arm. For ten points, name this quantity denoted tau, the rotational analogue of force which causes objects to rotate.

questions.first_sentence: This physicist developed a method of "reciprocal figures" for analyzing whether structures are statically indeterminate.
questions.text: This physicist developed a method of "reciprocal figures" for analyzing whether structures are statically indeterminate. Along with Josef Stefan, this physicist names a model of diffusion, and he names several laws of thermodynamics about the mixed partial derivatives of thermodynamic potentials. He is the second alphabetical namesake of a distribution which gives the (*) speeds of particles in an ideal gas in equilibrium. This physicist developed a set of equations which can be used to calculate the speed of electromagnetic wave propagation. For ten points, name this physicist who names a "demon" which seemingly violates the Second Law of Thermodynamics as well as the set of four equations which govern electromagnetism.

questions.first_sentence: One character in this play becomes irritated at another character’s choice of the word “illusion.”
questions.text: One character in this play becomes irritated at another character’s choice of the word “illusion.” Another character in this play is called “worse than mad” after performing Prenez garde à Tchou-Tchin-Tchou. At the end of this play, one character exclaims, “Pretence? Reality? To Hell with it all!” and claims that he wasted an entire day. In this play, coats and (*) hats are put on pegs to summon the shop-owner Madame Pace [PAH-chay]. The play-within-a-play Mixing it Up is botched in this play, in which the Child drowns in a fountain and the Son shoots himself with a revolver. For 10 points, name this play in which the Father, the Step-Daughter and the other title characters seek a writer, written by Luigi Pirandello.

questions.first_sentence: This star defines an apparent magnitude of 0 in photometric bands in visual wavelengths.
questions.text: This star defines an apparent magnitude of 0 in photometric bands in visual wavelengths. This star is the prototype of stars which emit infrared light as the result of a circumstellar disc of dust. The surface temperature of this star's poles and equator differ by about 2500 Kelvin, this is a result of its large equatorial bulge. Axial (*) precession will cause this star to replace Polaris as the pole star of the Northern Hemisphere in 12000 years. This star's Flamsteed designation is 3 Lyrae, while its Bayer designation is Alpha Lyrae. For 10 points, name this star which along with Altair and Deneb, forms the Summer Triangle

questions.first_sentence: Absolute magnitude is correlated with a certain properties of one of these objects in the Wilson-Bappu effect.
questions.text: Absolute magnitude is correlated with a certain properties of one of these objects in the Wilson-Bappu effect. The Abbe number is determined by observing three of these objects. The splitting of the 3p energy level into states with j=3/2 and j=½ is responsible a well known pair of these entities. The namesake of these objects also names far field diffraction. D1 and D2, the sodium doublet, are an example of these objects. William Wollaston was the first person to observe these dark objects on the sun, but their namesake was the first to measure their wavelengths. For 10 points, name these absorption lines found in the Sun absorption.

questions.first_sentence: In one novel by this author, Merlin causes a dragon to breathe mist that causes the entire country to lose its memory.
questions.text: In one novel by this author, Merlin causes a dragon to breathe mist that causes the entire country to lose its memory. In another novel by this author, students submit artwork to a Gallery that doesn’t actually exist. This author created Axl and Beatrice in a novel about Arthurian England, while in another of this man’s novels, two characters are convinced that loving each other will result in a (*) “deferral.” This author of The Buried Giant wrote a novel in which students at Hailsham are raised to be organ donors, while in another novel, one character recalls his affairs with Miss Kenton and his service under Lord Darlington. For ten points each, name this author of Never Let Me Go, who created the butler Stevens in The Remains of the Day.

questions.first_sentence: In one novel by this author, Howard employs his photographic memory to win big on a TV quiz show.
questions.text: In one novel by this author, Howard employs his photographic memory to win big on a TV quiz show. This author created a teacher at the Mansor school named Victor Crabbe who is afraid that a Communist student is running indoctrination sessions. This author of One Hand Clapping included Time for a Tiger in his Malayan Trilogy. One character created this author rapes two young girls he found at a record store and is described as “Your (*) Humble Narrator.” That character has nausea induced at the sight of graphic films and the music of “Lovely Ludwig Van” as part of the Ludovico technique, meant to resolve his obsession with “ultraviolence.” For ten points, name this author who created the delinquent teen Alex in A Clockwork Orange.

questions.first_sentence: E. Faecalis has been observed to slowly evolve immunity to a drug which targets this organelle by binding to domain V, those drugs are oxazolidinones.
questions.text: E. Faecalis has been observed to slowly evolve immunity to a drug which targets this organelle by binding to domain V, those drugs are oxazolidinones. A Fungus of the genus Fusidium produce a different drug which targets this structure. The antifungal cycloheximide functions by targeting this structure. One method of targeting this structure does so by preventing the turnover of EF-G. Many drugs which target this structure, including pleuromutilin and macrolides, do so by inhibiting peptidyl transferase. Tetracyclines inhibit this structure by blocking the attachment of aminoacyl tRNA to the A site. Drugs that target this structure usually target either the 50S or 30S subunits. For 10 points, name this structure, which is targeted to inhibit protein synthesis.

questions.first_sentence: The speaker of this poem states his soul will become louder “for every tatter in its mortal dress.
questions.text: The speaker of this poem states his soul will become louder “for every tatter in its mortal dress.” The speaker of this poem, who describes monuments “caught in that sensual music all neglect,” imagines his body “in such a form as Grecian Goldsmiths make.” The speaker of this poem wishes to “set upon a golden bough to sing to lords and ladies of” the title place, and also wishes to be gathered “into the (*) artifice of eternity.” In this poem, the narrator compares humans to “salmon-falls” and “mackerel-crowded seas.” In this poem, the speaker claims that “an aged man is a paltry thing” and opens the poem by saying, “That is no country for old men.” For ten points, name this William Butler Yeats poem about a journey to Constantinople.

questions.first_sentence: The speaker of this poem states his soul will become louder “for every tatter in its mortal dress.
questions.text: The speaker of this poem states his soul will become louder “for every tatter in its mortal dress.” The speaker of this poem, who describes monuments “caught in that sensual music all neglect,” imagines his body “in such a form as Grecian Goldsmiths make.” The speaker of this poem wishes to “set upon a golden bough to sing to lords and ladies of” the title place, and also wishes to be gathered “into the (*) artifice of eternity.” In this poem, the narrator compares humans to “salmon-falls” and “mackerel-crowded seas.” In this poem, the speaker claims that “an aged man is a paltry thing” and opens the poem by saying, “That is no country for old men.” For ten points, name this William Butler Yeats poem about a journey to Constantinople.

questions.first_sentence: In this region’s namesake “pump” theory, the precession of the Earth’s axis causes this region to have “wet” and “dry” stages every 41,000 years.
questions.text: In this region’s namesake “pump” theory, the precession of the Earth’s axis causes this region to have “wet” and “dry” stages every 41,000 years. Located west of the Hoggar Mountains, the Tanezrouft is the most extreme subdivision of this region with maximum high temperatures of 125 degrees Fahrenheit. Emi Koussi and Bikku Bitti are the two highest points in this region and are located within the Tibesti Mountains. This region is separated from the Sudanian Savanna by the Sahel. Home to sand dunes known as “ergs,” for ten points, name this desert that covers most of North Africa.

questions.first_sentence: In a stream-of-consciousness chapter of a novel by this author, a character constantly refers to her mother as “a hot thing.”
questions.text: In a stream-of-consciousness chapter of a novel by this author, a character constantly refers to her mother as “a hot thing.” That character created by this author asks “You rememory me?” in a sequence of three intertwining disembodied voices only heard by women. This author wrote a novel whose main character explains that she has a “tree” on her back because of beatings she received from Schoolteacher. This author wrote a novel that begins “124 Bluestone Road was spiteful,” in which Paul D helps nurse an escaped slave back to health. For 10 points, name this American author who wrote about Sethe’s murder of her infant daughter in her novel Beloved.

questions.first_sentence: An e. e. cummings poem about carrying one of these objects includes the lines “here is the deepest secret nobody knows,” and the speaker of a Byron poem asks a “Maid ofAthens” to give back one of these objects before they part ways.
questions.text: An e. e. cummings poem about carrying one of these objects includes the lines “here is the deepest secret nobody knows,” and the speaker of a Byron poem asks a “Maid ofAthens” to give back one of these objects before they part ways. These body parts are “torn and bleeding” in Paul Laurence Dunbar’s “We Wear the Mask,” and John Donne askeda “three-personed God” to batter this organ. This internal organ is a “Lonely Hunter” in the title of a Carson McCullers novel. For 10 points, name this internal organ which is “Tell-Tale” in an Edgar Allan Poe story.

questions.first_sentence: This author wrote six different variations of a story about John and Mary’s death in “Happy Endings.
questions.text: This author wrote six different variations of a story about John and Mary’s death in “Happy Endings.” This author, who retold the Odyssey from a female perspective in the Penelopiad, created a protagonist who steals butter to use as lotion and is resented by Serena Joy. In that novel by this author, the protagonist plays Scrabble with the Commander, which is forbidden in the Republic of Gilead. For 10 points, name this Canadian author who wrote about Offred [“of-fred”] in The Handmaid’s Tale.

questions.first_sentence: In the prologue of one work written in this language, the speaker describes an object that moves “men and women to tears.”
questions.text: In the prologue of one work written in this language, the speaker describes an object that moves “men and women to tears.” “The Song of the Reed-Flute” was written in this language, and serves as the prologue for the poetry collection Spiritual Couplets. Another poetry collection written in this language describes how “the moving finger writes,” and consists of 51 quatrains. In an Edward Fitzgerald translation of a poetry collection in this language, the speaker wishes for “a jug of wine, a loaf of bread, and Thou beside [him].” For 10 points, name this language used by Omar Khayyam to write the Rubaiyat.

questions.first_sentence: This event was code-named Operation Holy Tuesday, and a neighboring nation handled diversions resulting from this event in Operation Yellow Ribbon.
questions.text: This event was code-named Operation Holy Tuesday, and a neighboring nation handled diversions resulting from this event in Operation Yellow Ribbon. After this event, Article 5 of the NATO Charter was invoked for the first time. This event was planned by Khalid Sheikh Mohammed, and Mohammed Atta led a group from Hamburg in carrying out this event. During this event, some passengers on United Flight 93 were able to crash-land their aircraft in Pennsylvania, but other hijacked planes destroyed the World Trade Center. For 10 points, name this terrorist attack by al-Qaeda.

questions.first_sentence: This element combines with carbon to form carborundum, which is used as an abrasive.
questions.text: This element combines with carbon to form carborundum, which is used as an abrasive. NMR spectroscopy using its 29 isotope can be used to analyze zeolites. This element is used to produce mass amounts of magnesium metal via the Pidgeon Process. It can undergo catenation, similar to alkanes, as it is located below carbon on the periodic table. This non-germanium element is commonly used as a semiconductor, and it combines with oxygen to form quartz. For 10 points, name this metalloid used to make computer chips with symbol Si.

questions.first_sentence: In this novel, the protagonist compares his mother's buttocks to a "black mango."
questions.text: In this novel, the protagonist compares his mother's buttocks to a "black mango." Another character in this novel is convinced by Joseph D’Costa’s ghost to confess to a crime she committed on the Methwold Estate. In this novel, the protagonist is switched at birth with(*) Shiva-of- the-Knees, and his moment of birth lines up with the partition of India, which gives him special telepathic powers. For 10 points, name this novel about Saleem Sinai, written by Salman Rushdie.

questions.first_sentence: This conflict was preceded by a border raid at Samua called Operation Shredder.
questions.text: This conflict was preceded by a border raid at Samua called Operation Shredder. After this conflict, Hafez al-Assad nearly lost his job as his country’s defense minister, and theKhartoum Resolution’s “Three No’s” were adopted. A major cause of this non-Suez Crisis war was the blockade of Eilat, and this war began with the surprise Operation Focus, which destroyed most of Egypt’s air force while it was on the ground. Gains for this war’s winning side included Gaza and the West Bank. For 10 points, name this war in which an Arab coalition suffered a swift and decisive loss to Israel in June 1967.

questions.first_sentence: A character in this novel learns French by eavesdropping on a reading of Ruins of Empires.
questions.text: A character in this novel learns French by eavesdropping on a reading of Ruins of Empires. The books The Sorrows of Werter and Paradise Lost influence one character in this novel, and lead him to resent his “accursed Creator.” This novel’s title character studies Agrippa and Paracelsus at Ingolstadt, and sees his brother William and his friend Henry Clerval murdered by his creation. For 10 points, name this novel about Victor and the monster he makes from human body parts, written by Mary Shelley.

questions.first_sentence: One work about these events discusses Conrad Stoeckhlin as a “virtuoso performer of popular culture” and bricoleur.
questions.text: One work about these events discusses Conrad Stoeckhlin as a “virtuoso performer of popular culture” and bricoleur. Another microhistory explaining the origin of these events traces an ancient fertility cult in which people’s spirits would supposedly battle malevolent outsiders that threatened local crops. These books are Wolfgang Behringer’s Shaman of Obserstdorf and Ginzburg’s The Night Battles. One book describing these events helped changed perceptions of victims of these events from educated males to uneducated females and was Johannes Nider’s Formicarius. Notable locations of these events include Trier, Fulda, and Wurzburg. A handbook used to guide these events, written by Sprenger and Kramer is the Malleus Maleficarum. For 10 points, name these events that often lead to the burning of women accused of consorting with the devil.

questions.first_sentence: A journalist in this country, Rifat Çetin, was given a suspended prison sentence for comparing this country’s president to Gollum from Lord of the Rings, and in 2013 a group called “Ergenekon” was alleged to be plotting against this country’s government.
questions.text: A journalist in this country, Rifat Çetin, was given a suspended prison sentence for comparing this country’s president to Gollum from Lord of the Rings, and in 2013 a group called “Ergenekon” was alleged to be plotting against this country’s government. In July 2016, the actions of a group called the “Peace at Home Council” resulted in the occupation of Taksim Square and the closure of the Bosphorus Bridge in this country. For the points, name this country where Recep Tayyip Erdogan governs from Ankara, the site of an alleged coup.

questions.first_sentence: One artwork of this type designed by Nicola Salvi includes figures representing “Abundance” and “Health,” the latter of whom holds a cup for a snake.
questions.text: One artwork of this type designed by Nicola Salvi includes figures representing “Abundance” and “Health,” the latter of whom holds a cup for a snake. That work features two hippocamps flanking the central figure of Oceanus. An art piece titled after one of these structures carries the signature “R. Mutt,” although the true artist was Marcel Duchamp. A famous structure of this type features an Egyptian obelisk as well as figures representing the Nile, Ganges, Danube, and Rio de la Plata. For the points, name these water-dispensing structures, examples of which include Bernini’s one “of the Four Rivers.”

questions.first_sentence: This figure was formed out of water and clay by the goddess Aruru, and he is described as being shaggy with “locks like a woman.”
questions.text: This figure was formed out of water and clay by the goddess Aruru, and he is described as being shaggy with “locks like a woman.” He throws meat in the face of the goddess Ishtar, and he is selected by the gods to die of a wasting illness after he and his companion kill the Bull of Heaven. This figure becomes civilized after spending six days and seven nights with the prostitute Shamhat, and he encourages his companion to kill the demon Humbaba as he begs for his life. For the points, name this “wild man” of Sumerian mythology, the beloved friend of Gilgamesh.

questions.first_sentence: In the Hebrew Bible, one of these figures cursed 42 youths, causing them to be killed by she-bears.
questions.text: In the Hebrew Bible, one of these figures cursed 42 youths, causing them to be killed by she-bears. Another one of these figures ascended to heaven in a whirlwind, and a seat is saved for him at every Passover seder. Mormons consider Joseph Smith and his successors to be examples these figures. In Islam, Jesus is believed to be one of these figures, and Muhammad is known as the “seal” of these figures. For the points, name these people such as Elisha, Elijah, and Isaiah, religious figures who speak directly to God.

questions.first_sentence: J. Robert Oppenheimer quoted this work after the first test of the atomic bomb, saying “Now I am become Death, the destroyer of worlds.
questions.text: J. Robert Oppenheimer quoted this work after the first test of the atomic bomb, saying “Now I am become Death, the destroyer of worlds.” Each of this work’s chapters pertains to a type of yoga, or discipline, and in a frame narrative it is told to the blind king Dhritarashtra by Sanjaya. This poem is structured as a dialogue between Arjuna and his charioteer Krishna as Krishna attempts to remind Arjuna of his duty as a warrior. For the points, name this Hindu scripture, a 700-verse section of the Mahabharata.

questions.first_sentence: The two main sources chronicling this conflict are known as the Bulletin and the Poem, and one commander in this battle made use of two Shasu spies.
questions.text: The two main sources chronicling this conflict are known as the Bulletin and the Poem, and one commander in this battle made use of two Shasu spies. A late arrival from Amurru by N’earin mercenaries helped turn the tide of this battle, which featured the rout of the Re division. A replica of the treaty that ended this conflict hangs in the United Nations building, since it is the earliest known example of an international agreement, and this was likely the largest chariot battle in history. For the points, name this battle that pitted the Hittite forces of Muwatalli II against Egyptians led by Ramses the Great.

questions.first_sentence: During this conflict, Spanish troops suffered heavy losses at the Battle of Krasny Bor, and Inigo Campioni saw his fleet destroyed at the Battle of Taranto.
questions.text: During this conflict, Spanish troops suffered heavy losses at the Battle of Krasny Bor, and Inigo Campioni saw his fleet destroyed at the Battle of Taranto. Crete was invaded during this conflict under Operation Mercury, and Harry Dexter White represented the U.S. at a New Hampshire conference discussing the end of this conflict. In addition to that meeting at Bretton Woods, this conflict featured conferences at Cairo, Tehran, and Yalta. For the points, name this conflict whose major offensives included Operation Barbarossa, the Battle of the Bulge, and D-Day.

questions.first_sentence: In one scene in this play, Le Bret comes onstage to whisper to the protagonist that another character has died from a gunshot heard offstage, but the protagonist inadvertently reveals his death to that man's lover when he uses the past tense to refer to him.
questions.text: In one scene in this play, Le Bret comes onstage to whisper to the protagonist that another character has died from a gunshot heard offstage, but the protagonist inadvertently reveals his death to that man's lover when he uses the past tense to refer to him. A woman in this play realizes that the title character has been writing her letters using another man's name when he continues reading a letter from memory despite the growing darkness. During a duel with (*) Valvert, the title character of this play improvises a poem and stabs his opponent as he utters the final line. The title character of this play assists Christian in the wooing of his cousin Roxane and is afflicted by his immense nose. For 10 points, name this play by Edmond Rostand about the titular poet.

questions.first_sentence: This establishment that these events are named for was owned by the Mafia at the time, and it was noteworthy for being the only place of its type that allowed dancing.
questions.text: This establishment that these events are named for was owned by the Mafia at the time, and it was noteworthy for being the only place of its type that allowed dancing. These events prominently featured homeless youth who slept in Christopher Park, and demonstrators at these events formed impromptu kicklines as they confronted police officers. In 2016, Barack Obama announced the creation of a national monument in Greenwich Village to protect the site of these events. For the points, identify these demonstrations named for a New York City gay bar.

questions.first_sentence: This state is the birthplace of businessman T. Boone Pickens and former U.N. Ambassador Jeane Kirkpatrick, and this modern-day state was the site of the Sequoyah Constitutional Convention in 1905.
questions.text: This state is the birthplace of businessman T. Boone Pickens and former U.N. Ambassador Jeane Kirkpatrick, and this modern-day state was the site of the Sequoyah Constitutional Convention in 1905. Race riots in this state resulted in the destruction of “Black Wall Street” in 1921, and the Alfred P. Murrah Federal Building in this state’s capital was the site of a 1995 terrorist attack. Thousands of Native Americans were forcibly relocated to this modern-day state on the Trail of Tears. For the points, name this “Sooner State” whose major cities include Muskogee and Tulsa.

questions.first_sentence: This man was arrested for his work with the Petrashevsky Circle and did four years of hard labor in Siberia.
questions.text: This man was arrested for his work with the Petrashevsky Circle and did four years of hard labor in Siberia. His novel The House of the Dead deals with his time in prison, and another novel focuses on Prince Myshkin, who suffers from epilepsy. Ivan has a nightmare about the devil and tells his brother Aloysha a story about “The Grand Inquisitor” in another of this man’s novels. The axe murder Raskolnikov is the protagonist of this man’s Crime and Punishment. For the points, name this Russian author of The Idiot and The Brothers Karamazov.

questions.first_sentence: The protagonist of this author’s first major novel spies on his mother by hiding in her washing-chest, but is discovered when a pajama cord goes up his gigantic nose.
questions.text: The protagonist of this author’s first major novel spies on his mother by hiding in her washing-chest, but is discovered when a pajama cord goes up his gigantic nose. That character, has special powers due to the hour of his birth and is named Saleem Sinai. This man wrote the children’s book Haroun and the Sea of Stories, and a controversial work by this author opens with Gibreel Farishta and Saladin Chamcha in a hijacked plane. Ayatollah Khomeini issued a fatwa calling for the death of, for the points, what Indian author of Midnight’s Children and The Satanic Verses?

questions.first_sentence: One novel set in this nation sees Peekay learn boxing from Geel Piet and become known as the “Tadpole Angel;” that novel is The Power of One.
questions.text: One novel set in this nation sees Peekay learn boxing from Geel Piet and become known as the “Tadpole Angel;” that novel is The Power of One. Another novel from this country involves Maureen Smales becoming inferior to her former servant and is titled July’s People. In another novel set in this nation, Absalom Kumalo [COO-mah-low] gets the death penalty for murdering Arthur Jarvis. Cry, the Beloved Country is a novel from, for the points, what home nation of Nadine Gordimer and Alan Paton, which lived under apartheid until 1994.

questions.first_sentence: One poem in this collection features a title figure who “lecture[s] with much applause in the lecture-room,” causing the speaker to become “tired and sick.”
questions.text: One poem in this collection features a title figure who “lecture[s] with much applause in the lecture-room,” causing the speaker to become “tired and sick.” Another poem in this collection begins “Flood-tide below me! I watch you face to face;” that poem is “Crossing Brooklyn Ferry.” Later editions of this collection featured two elegies for Abraham Lincoln, “When Lilacs Last In The Dooryard Bloom’d” and “O Captain! My Captain!” For the points, name this poetry collection that also features “Song of Myself,” the magnum opus of Walt Whitman.

questions.first_sentence: Lily Bart performs this action in The House of Mirth by Edith Wharton and Martha performs this action in The Children’s Hour by Lillian Hellman.
questions.text: Lily Bart performs this action in The House of Mirth by Edith Wharton and Martha performs this action in The Children’s Hour by Lillian Hellman. The protagonist performs this action at the end of “A Perfect Day for Bananafish,” and Joe Keller and Willy Loman carry out this action in two separate Arthur Miller plays. Two members of the Monzano family perform this action with “ice-nine” in Cat’s Cradle, and Quentin Compson does this in the Charles River after fastening tailor’s weights to his feet. In real life, Sylvia Plath performed this action by placing her head in an oven. For the points, name this self-inflicted method of death.

questions.first_sentence: In one of this author’s poems, the speaker sees his mother as “nineteen, and not a day older,” making clothes for him on the night before Christmas.
questions.text: In one of this author’s poems, the speaker sees his mother as “nineteen, and not a day older,” making clothes for him on the night before Christmas. In addition to “The Ballad of the Harp Weaver,” this poet wrote the collection A Few Figs From Thistles, in which she invites readers to “come and see my shining palace built upon the sand.” That collection also includes the famous line “My candle burns at both ends, it will not last the night.” For the points, name this female American poet.

questions.first_sentence: This character disguises himself as “Sarah Mary Williams,” but is discovered when he tries to thread a needle.
questions.text: This character disguises himself as “Sarah Mary Williams,” but is discovered when he tries to thread a needle. He also takes the alias “George Jackson” as he becomes embroiled in a family feud between the Grangerfords and Sheperdsons, and he encounters two con men called the Duke and Dauphin. He fakes his own death to escape his abusive father, Pap, and his plans to free Jim are unnecessarily complicated by Tom Sawyer. For the points, name this Mark Twain title character who takes off down the Mississippi.

questions.first_sentence: In this novel, wounds on the protagonist’s back are compared to a “chokecherry tree,” and this novel’s opening line contains the house number 124.
questions.text: In this novel, wounds on the protagonist’s back are compared to a “chokecherry tree,” and this novel’s opening line contains the house number 124. Schoolteacher, Stamp Paid, and Sixo are minor characters in this work, all of whom live on Sweet Home Plantation. Paul D is overcome by repressed memories of slavery when he sleeps with the title character, and Sethe spoils the title character because she believes the title character is her two-year-old daughter that she murdered. For the points, name this novel by Toni Morrison dedicated to “sixty million and more”.

questions.first_sentence: This story takes place in a town of three hundred people, which allows the central event to occur in less than two hours.
questions.text: This story takes place in a town of three hundred people, which allows the central event to occur in less than two hours. Surnames in this story include Martin, Summers, and Delacroix [DELL-uh-croy], and Old Man Warner is participating in the title event for the seventy-seventh time. This story’s central event is said to ensure a heavy corn harvest, and a black box is prominently featured. For the points, name this short story that ends with the public stoning of Tessie Hutchinson, the best-known work of Shirley Jackson.

questions.first_sentence: This event was preceded by riots in Noakhali, as well as a Direct Day of Action against the Cabinet Mission Plan that led to mass killings in the Week of the Long Knives.
questions.text: This event was preceded by riots in Noakhali, as well as a Direct Day of Action against the Cabinet Mission Plan that led to mass killings in the Week of the Long Knives. Writings supporting this event include the 1933 pamphlet “Now or Never,” published in the wake of the Round Table Conferences, as well as a resolution commemorated by a minaret-shaped monument in Iqbal Park. This action was carried out along the Radcliffe Line, which controversially neglected the Chittagong Hill Tracts and split the provinces of Bengal and Punjab. Lord Mountbatten was criticized for rushing this event, which saw massive population transfers and sectarian violence between Hindus and Muslims. For 10 points, name this August 1947 event that split the British Raj into two independent South Asian nations.

questions.first_sentence: One author blamed this man’s death on a publication “so savage and tartarly,” although that same author later wrote that it was strange this man’s mind
questions.text: One author blamed this man’s death on a publication “so savage and tartarly,” although that same author later wrote that it was strange this man’s mind “should let itself be snuffed out by an Article.” Another work commemorating this poet commands Urania to “lament anew” and claims this man “hath awakened from the dream of life.” That work, an elegy for this man, begins “I weep for Adonais—he is dead!” This poet was mocked for “low diction” in his “Sleep and Poetry” and dismissed as part of the “Cockney school” in a review for his Endymion, but he was venerated by the Pre-Raphaelite Brotherhood for such works as “La Belle Dame Sans Merci.” For ten points, name this English poet who produced some famous odes, including one “on a Grecian urn,” before dying at age 25.

questions.first_sentence: His mother was accused of poisoning by Ursula Reinhold after a failed abortion.
questions.text: His mother was accused of poisoning by Ursula Reinhold after a failed abortion. That trial is depicted in two operas: Tim Watts' opera depicts his mother sympathetically, while Hindemith's depicts his mother as a deranged madwoman. His novel Somnium depicts what the Earth might look like from the moon and is considered an early work of Science Fiction. He also composed the Rudolphine Tables of planetary tables named in honor of his patron Rudolf II. By positing two foci, his elipses better explained orbits than the Copernican model. For 10 points, name this student of Tycho Brahe and formulator of the laws of planetary motion.

questions.first_sentence: Dissidents of this leader’s regime hijacked the Santa Maria cruise liner in Operation Dulcinea.
questions.text: Dissidents of this leader’s regime hijacked the Santa Maria cruise liner in Operation Dulcinea. Many political prisoners died in the Tarrafal prison camp established by this leader’s regime. Humbert Delgado was assassinated by this leader’s PIDE secret police. For 10 points, name this Portugese leader who established the Estado Novo regime.

questions.first_sentence: The Eightfold Way was proposed independently by Yuval Ne'eman and Murray Gell-Mann to organize these things by their strangeness into octets and decuplets.
questions.text: The Eightfold Way was proposed independently by Yuval Ne'eman and Murray Gell-Mann to organize these things by their strangeness into octets and decuplets. Jets of this class of particles can be observed after collisions of high energy particles in a process known by their name followed by (*) “-ization,” since their constituents spontaneously combine due to color confinement. These composite particles are divided into two families based on whether they are composed of two or three valence quarks. The world’s most powerful particle collider is named after these things, since it collides the only stable, free type of them, the proton. For 10 points, give this name for the general class of particles that includes baryons and mesons and are tested at the LHC.

questions.first_sentence: This letter denotes a quantity which describes the compensation of the loss of chemical potential from the addition of a solute.
questions.text: This letter denotes a quantity which describes the compensation of the loss of chemical potential from the addition of a solute. That quantity denoted by this letter is computed as the product of the molar concentration, the ideal gas constant, the temperature, and the van ’t Hoff factor, and is known as the (*) osmotic pressure. According to Hückel’s Rule, aromatic molecules are characterized by 4n+2 electrons designated by this letter, and bonds designated by this letter occur when two lobes of an atomic orbital overlap with two lobes of another atomic orbital. For 10 points, identify this letter which denotes bonds that are weaker than sigma bonds and also denotes the ratio of a circle’s circumference to its diameter.

questions.first_sentence: A sound called the Bergie Seltzer is made when these structures degrade.
questions.text: A sound called the Bergie Seltzer is made when these structures degrade. A letter and number is assigned to every one of these structures, based on the longitude of their origin. The two basic forms of these formations are tabular and non-tabular. A loud cracking noise often precedes when these structures are formed in a process called (*) calving. These mobile structures can cause seabed gouging when oceanic currents move them towards shallower waters. For 10 points, name these geological features, of which only 10% of their size can be seen above sea level due to the properties of water’s density in different phases.

questions.first_sentence: Niccolò Paganini’s work “The Moses Fantasy” is a set of variations on the G string on a theme originally written by this composer.
questions.text: Niccolò Paganini’s work “The Moses Fantasy” is a set of variations on the G string on a theme originally written by this composer. When this composer was twelve years old, he composed six string sonatas scored for two violins, cello, and double bass called sonate a quattro. In this composer’s overture to (*) Il Signor Bruschino, the second violins are instructed to tap their bows on their music stands. This composer also wrote a work in which an E minor thunderstorm is followed by a pastoral Ranz des Vaches featuring the English horn before leading to a famous galop. For 10 points, name this Italian composer of many famous overtures such as the aforementioned William Tell Overture.

questions.first_sentence: . This man is replaced with a Zibhin azeem, or “great sacrifice,” after copper appears on him to prevent his death at the hand of his father.
questions.text: . This man is replaced with a Zibhin azeem, or “great sacrifice,” after copper appears on him to prevent his death at the hand of his father. After this man’s mother ran back and forth between the hills of Al-Safa and Al-Marwah seven times, this figure scratched the ground with his heel to produce the (*) Well of Zamzam. That event took place after this figure and his mother were sent away because of his mother-in-law’s jealousy. This figure married two women from Jurhum, and he traveled to Mecca with Ibrahim to build the Kaaba. For 10 points, name this patriarch who was the brother-in-law of Ishaq and the first-born of Ibrahim by his mother Haajar.

questions.first_sentence: The Roche Limit describes the distance at which these structures will form from surrounding particulates.
questions.text: The Roche Limit describes the distance at which these structures will form from surrounding particulates. Thirteen of these structures have been identified since 1977 in association with Uranus. Rhea was the first moon in our solar system speculated to have these structures, although other imaging suggested magnetism interfered with imaging. (*) Tidal deceleration leads scientists to believe that Phobos will break up in the next fifty million years and become Mars’ first one of these structures. For 10 points, name these disc-shaped structures that are most prominently located around Saturn.

questions.first_sentence: 136 bars of this chord appears for four minutes straight in one prelude depicting the motion of the river Rhine, and Robert Schumann’s visit to the Rhineland inspired his third symphony, which is also in this key.
questions.text: 136 bars of this chord appears for four minutes straight in one prelude depicting the motion of the river Rhine, and Robert Schumann’s visit to the Rhineland inspired his third symphony, which is also in this key. A nocturne by Chopin in this key begins with the right hand playing a major sixth up to the third of this key, followed by scale degrees 2-3-2... 1. In addition to that (*) Opus 9 Number 2 work, other pieces in this key include Haydn’s Joke Quartet, an Octet by Mendelssohn, and Beethoven’s Emperor Concerto. Beethoven viewed this key as majestic and heroic, which refers back to the nickname given to his Symphony Number 3 in this key, “Eroica.” For 10 points, name this key with three flats, which is the relative major of C minor.

questions.first_sentence: Joan Miró’s painting The Tilled Field shows a background sky of this color.
questions.text: Joan Miró’s painting The Tilled Field shows a background sky of this color. Salvador Dalí’s painting The Great Masturbator features a giant distorted face of this color in the shape of a rock formation, and in Marc Chagall’s I and the Village, the (*) chapel and rightmost house are this color. A 1925 Kandinsky painting is titled after this color with red and blue, and JMW Turner experimented with the Indian pigment of this color derived from the urine of mango-fed cows. Though not green, this is the color of the titular figure hanging on a cross in a painting by Paul Gauguin. For 10 points, give this color that covers most of van Gogh’s Sunflower.

questions.first_sentence: One of these stories tells of Romos, a son of Odysseus and Circe who leaves home by ship.
questions.text: One of these stories tells of Romos, a son of Odysseus and Circe who leaves home by ship. The two most well known of these stories famously differ in that the first is based on fratricide, rape, and sheltering of criminals, where the second is based on the noble travels of a (*) Trojan War survivor. To resolve the problem of a nearly 700 year gap between those two well-known stories about this, ancient authors compiled a list of Alban kings who supposedly ruled in that gap. In one of these stories, the king offers shelter to criminals and vagrants to build a population of men, and abducts the Sabine Women as their brides. For 10 points, name these stories, which include stories of Romulus killing his brother Remus, and Aeneas ruling the city of Alba Longa.

questions.first_sentence: This man first put down a coup d’etat by Lao Ai, who had a longtime secret correspondence with this man’s mother, Lady Zhao.
questions.text: This man first put down a coup d’etat by Lao Ai, who had a longtime secret correspondence with this man’s mother, Lady Zhao. Following this man’s death, two carriages carrying rotten fish were drawn behind this man’s wagon in order to hide the smell of this man’s decaying body. The conquests of this man’s kingdom ultimately brought about the end of the (*) Warring States. This man, aside from constructing the precursor of the Great Wall of China, also consumed a deadly quantity of mercury, having believed that he would achieve immortality. For 10 points, name this first emperor of China, the mastermind of the Terracotta Army.

questions.first_sentence: One member of this profession searches for his lost cat and is aided by his assistant Louise Munroe; that man is Jackson Brodie and was included in a novel series by Kate Atkinson.
questions.text: One member of this profession searches for his lost cat and is aided by his assistant Louise Munroe; that man is Jackson Brodie and was included in a novel series by Kate Atkinson. Another member of this profession is called the greatest one of this profession of all time and sends Miss Carnaby two hundred pounds prior to the conclusion of her dog-kidnapping campaign in (*) The Nemean Lion. Yet another member of this profession appears to know nothing of “literature, philosophy and politics,” according to his assistant. That member of this profession faked his own death at Reichenbach Falls and was enamored by Irene Adler in “A Scandal in Bohemia.” For 10 points, identify this profession of Agatha Christie’s Hercule Poirot and Arthur Conan Doyle’s Sherlock Holmes.

questions.first_sentence: In one story, this deity splits into three parts and becomes known as Tripathaga.
questions.text: In one story, this deity splits into three parts and becomes known as Tripathaga. This deities’ death is often seen as one of the signs of the end of the Kali Yuga. When this deity destroyed the fields of Jahnu, he consumed her, and only after begging from the other gods was she released. The souls of the (*) six thousand sons of Sagara were cleansed by this deity, though she tried to destroy the entire world first. Bhagiratha prayed that Shiva would stop this deity from doing so, and Shiva trapped her in his hair, and redirected her anger, resulting in the common image of Shiva with flowing hair. For 10 points, name this deity, the personification of a vast purifying river in Hindu Religion.

questions.first_sentence: During the Lepers’ Plot of 1321, King Philip V [“the fifth”] ordered about five thousand lepers who had been accused of poisoning wells to be killed in this way.
questions.text: During the Lepers’ Plot of 1321, King Philip V [“the fifth”] ordered about five thousand lepers who had been accused of poisoning wells to be killed in this way. Jacques de Molay and William Tyndale died in this manner, and Charles the Bad died through these means after his physician wrapped him from (*) neck to toe in linen cloth soaked with brandy. Only six deaths were recorded in an event of this type that began at the bakery of Thomas Farriner on Pudding Lane; that event caused the destruction of a large portion of houses and churches in London in 1666. For 10 points, identify this means of death which Diocletian used to kills Christians and destroy their scriptures, and which Nero was purported to have ignored by playing the fiddle.

questions.first_sentence: One observer of this event tweeted, “Immigrants they get the job done” with regards to a participant in this event, even though the participant was born in America.
questions.text: One observer of this event tweeted, “Immigrants they get the job done” with regards to a participant in this event, even though the participant was born in America. A participant in this event, Bruno Massot, received citizenship in his naturalized country only three months prior to this event. The “Garlic Girls” from the home nation of this event produced an unprecedented run in their respective (*) sport, before conceding to Sweden prior to the tenth end. Red-uniformed cheerleading squads led choreographed chants at multiple venues at this event. U.S. Vice President Mike Pence and North Korean figure Kim Yo-jong sat next to each other at the Opening Ceremony of, for 10 points, what February 2018 international sporting event.

questions.first_sentence: In this myth system, one god crushes a jellyfish for failing to bring a monkey’s liver back to him.
questions.text: In this myth system, one god crushes a jellyfish for failing to bring a monkey’s liver back to him. A goddess in the myth system eats the food of the underworld, and becomes hideous. That goddess declared that she would kill a thousand people a day, and her husband retorted that he would bring back 1500. That goddess from this system had died giving birth to the (*) fire god. In this myth system, the moon god killed the food goddess when she threw up her meal, and the storm god killed an eight-headed, eight-tailed dragon by getting all of the heads drunk and then cutting the beast to pieces. For 10 points, name this myth system, where the sun goddess hid in a cave when her brother Susano’o threw a flayed pony into her chamber.

questions.first_sentence: The “Transcendental Aesthetic” section of Kant’s Critique of Pure Reason defines this thing as the “form of pure intuition” corresponding to the “inner sense.
questions.text: The “Transcendental Aesthetic” section of Kant’s Critique of Pure Reason defines this thing as the “form of pure intuition” corresponding to the “inner sense.” In the eleventh book of St. Augustine’s [au-GUS-tin’s] Confessions, he struggles to grasp this concept but eventually concludes that God must exist outside of it. J. M. E. McTaggart’s work about the (*) unreality of this concept argues that an absolute form of it is self-contradictory and that a “B-theory” of this concept implies its tenselessness. A-theorists of this thing believe it flows along a single causal line. For 10 points, give this concept studied in the fields of Presentism and Eternalism, which Aristotle in his work Physics defines as “a number of change with respect to the before and after.”

questions.first_sentence: American conductor Gunther Schuller offers a musical analysis on the unique solo improvisation techniques exhibited in a work whose title contains this word followed by “seven.”
questions.text: American conductor Gunther Schuller offers a musical analysis on the unique solo improvisation techniques exhibited in a work whose title contains this word followed by “seven.” Another piece with this word in the title is notable for its use of aksak meter, grouping beats into three measures of 2, 2, 2, 3 and one measure of 3, 3, 3; that piece is called “[this word] (*) Rondo à la Turk.” A song on an album whose name contains this adjective is characterized by alternating sections in D Dorian mode and E-flat Dorian mode; that album titled for this color is by Miles Davis. For 10 points, name this adjective used to describe a European river in a waltz by Johann Strauss II, as well as a rhapsody by George Gershwin.

questions.first_sentence: On the first night of this battle, the generals of the defending force were at a party hosted by Admiral Stark.
questions.text: On the first night of this battle, the generals of the defending force were at a party hosted by Admiral Stark. Fortifications were sent to the nearby town of Dalny prior to this battle, which was incited by a surprise nighttime torpedo attack by Admiral Togo that took out two Russian battleships. Diplomatic ties were cut between (*) Russia and Japan two days before this 1904 battle, which was named for the then-Russian naval base at the tip of the Liaodong Peninsula in Manchuria. For 10 points, name this largely inconclusive naval battle which is often considered the first battle of the Russo-Japanese War.

questions.first_sentence: n internal type of this region named for Cauchy occurs when the Reissner–Nordström metric is applied to a charged type of body associated with this region.
questions.text: n internal type of this region named for Cauchy occurs when the Reissner–Nordström metric is applied to a charged type of body associated with this region. In the Kerr metric, the ergosphere touches this region at the poles of a rotating type of body associated with this region. When pair production overlaps with this boundary, blackbody (*) radiation named for Hawking occurs. In a Penrose diagram, this region is represented by a line with slope c, and an observer will never see objects enter this region, instead observing an approaching object become increasingly redshifted and slow to a halt. Light emitted from within this boundary will never escape. For 10 points, name this “point of no return” that defines the boundary of a black hole.

questions.first_sentence: The English chemist John Mayow called an allotrope of this element spiritus nitroaereus after experiments he conducted with antimony, water, mice, and candles.
questions.text: The English chemist John Mayow called an allotrope of this element spiritus nitroaereus after experiments he conducted with antimony, water, mice, and candles. This element was produced in experiments conducted by Pierre Bayen and by Robert Hooke, though they did not recognize its chemical form, instead hypothesizing that this element’s consumption was actually the release of (*) phlogiston. This element was first discovered by Carl Wilhelm Scheele, who called it “fire air,” and this element was given its modern name from the Greek for “acid producer” by Antoine Lavoisier because he incorrectly believed all acids contain this element. For 10 points, name this element which Priestly called “dephlogisticated air,” whose diatomic form makes up 21% of the atmosphere.

questions.first_sentence: Mayor Patricia de Lille, in anticipation of this event, has urged high tariffs for those who consume more than 50 liters per day.
questions.text: Mayor Patricia de Lille, in anticipation of this event, has urged high tariffs for those who consume more than 50 liters per day. Approximately 37,000 agricultural jobs have been lost in light of this event, which is expected to arrive in August 2018 if the annual August rains do not come. In October 2017, officials announced that the city manager may forego standard legislation to accelerate the construction of (*) desalination plants in anticipation of this event. A prolonged 2014 El Niño has led to a once-in-a-century drought that has caused, for 10 points, what public dilemma in which a South African city runs out of a certain public utility?

questions.first_sentence: According to Cassius Dio, the beginning of this thing occurred when Commodus ascended to the throne.
questions.text: According to Cassius Dio, the beginning of this thing occurred when Commodus ascended to the throne. Other markers of the start of this process include the death of Julius Nepos and the Military Anarchy of the third century. This process continued until Romulus Augustulus was deposed by (*) Odoacer, and one writer notes that the spread of Christianity caused a loss of civic virtue that helped bring about this process. The recovery of the Balkans by Theodosius attempted to avert this process but only succeeded in delaying it. For 10 points, name this process chronicled in a 1776 work by the historian Edward Gibbon, in which a series of barbarian tribes warred against and destroyed the most powerful Empire in Europe.

questions.first_sentence: Ezekiel chapter 34 prophesies against a people in Israel with this profession, since they feed and clothe themselves without worrying about others.
questions.text: Ezekiel chapter 34 prophesies against a people in Israel with this profession, since they feed and clothe themselves without worrying about others. In John 21 after Jesus asks Simon Peter if he loves him, he metaphorically imparts this profession on Peter, and in John 10, Jesus calls himself the (*) good type of this profession. An apocryphal New Testament book is named for this profession “of Hermas,” and in Psalm 23, the Lord is said to be this profession for the speaker. In the Nativity story, a host of angels appear to people with this profession living in the countryside. For 10 points, name this profession related in Latin to the term “pastor,” people who watch over flocks.

questions.first_sentence: New York v. U.S. saw the first application of this in over 55 years to invalidate a legislative act.
questions.text: New York v. U.S. saw the first application of this in over 55 years to invalidate a legislative act. In Printz v. U.S., Scalia invalidated the Brady Handgun Violence Prevention Act using this as justification. A recent and notable application of this was in the Supreme Court case National Federation of Independent Business v. (*) Sebelius, in which the majority opinion used this to invalidate parts of the Affordable Care Act which supposedly coerced states into opting for Medicaid expansion. This constitutional amendment originally included the word “expressly,” but it was later omitted by Roger Sherman at the objection of James Madison. For 10 points, name this Constitutional amendment which enshrines American federalism, the last in the Bill of Rights.

questions.first_sentence: espite dying of typhoid fever, this man’s cause of death was originally reported by the pro-Federalist Gazette of the United States to be illness of the liver.
questions.text: espite dying of typhoid fever, this man’s cause of death was originally reported by the pro-Federalist Gazette of the United States to be illness of the liver. This man’s only education was received from the Reverend Samuel Dunbar, but he later became a treasurer for Yale College. This man’s son-in-law, Simeon Baldwin, succeeded him in a post of which he was the inaugural holder; that post was Mayor of (*) New Haven, Connecticut. Despite being originally opposed to the idea of replacing the Articles of Confederation, this man would go on to propose the Connecticut Compromise. For 10 points, name this Founding Father, the only man other than Robert Morris to sign the Declaration of Independence, Articles of Confederation, and the U.S. Constitution.

questions.first_sentence: A musical theme that depicts this animal begins with the staccato ascending then descending notes D G B, G D C-sharp.
questions.text: A musical theme that depicts this animal begins with the staccato ascending then descending notes D G B, G D C-sharp. A humorous duet often attributed to Rossini calls for two of these creatures in its title, though it is written for two sopranos who sing only one word. A sonata in G minor by Domenico Scarlatti is a fugue named for this creature, inspired by one called (*) Pulcinella walking across Scarlatti’s keyboard. In Prokofiev’s Peter and the Wolf, this animal is depicted with the clarinet. A musical titled after a tribe of these creatures is based on a work by T. S. Eliot and includes the characters Jennyanydots and Skimbleshanks. For 10 points, name these creatures whose tribe called the Jellicles appears in a musical by Andrew Lloyd Webber.

questions.first_sentence: The most recent addition to this book’s series was written by the author of Artemis Fowl, Eoin Colfer.
questions.text: The most recent addition to this book’s series was written by the author of Artemis Fowl, Eoin Colfer. The author of this book notes that his inspiration came while lying drunk in the middle of an Austrian field, clutching a more serious book of a similar title. This novel was adapted from a comical science fiction (*) BBC radio series of the same name, which began airing in 1978. In this book, Earth is demolished by an alien race known as the Vogons to build a bypass for an intergalactic highway. The novel’s protagonist, Arthur Dent, and Ford Prefect go on journey through the universe and encounter a super computer which has calculated the Ultimate Answer to Life, the Universe, and Everything to be 42. For 10 points, name this science fiction novel by Douglas Adams.

questions.first_sentence: One work that supports the “free spirit” argues that that this concept was transformed from the state of nature by the weak who resented the strong.
questions.text: One work that supports the “free spirit” argues that that this concept was transformed from the state of nature by the weak who resented the strong. St. Irenaeus claimed that this concept is necessary for humans to fully develop into the likeness of God, while St. Augustine asserted in his Theodicy that this concept was not created by God but was a result of free will. Leibniz believed that the existence of this concept was proof against the omnipotence, benevolence, or existence of God. For ten points, name this paradigmatic concept, often used in the context of religion to mean something that is opposed to “good.”

questions.first_sentence: This site was discussed in an account by the Chinese diplomat Zhou Daguan, who reported a local legend that it had been constructed in one night by a prophetic artist.
questions.text: This site was discussed in an account by the Chinese diplomat Zhou Daguan, who reported a local legend that it had been constructed in one night by a prophetic artist. This site’s design is meant to reflect the peaks of Mount Meru. It was originally believed to have been conceived by the god Indra for his son, but most historians agree that construction was initiated by Suryavarman II. It would later become a popular pilgrimage destination for Japanese Buddhists despite originally being built to honor the god Vishnu. For ten points, name this temple complex built by the Khmer, the largest religious building in the world.

questions.first_sentence: earliest event given this name occured during a march in London against British oppression of Ireland.
questions.text: earliest event given this name occured during a march in London against British oppression of Ireland. An event with this name in Bydgoszcz [BID-goshch] was used to drum up support for the German invasion of Poland. The first day of the Battle of Paardeberg during the Second Boer War was given this name, as was the beating of protesters by police during the Selma to Montgomery March. This name was given to a massacre in St. Petersburg that kicked off the Russian Revolution of 1905. For ten points, give this name applied to the Bogside Massacre of civilians in Derry by the British Army in 1972, which occured on the so-called “day of rest.”

questions.first_sentence: One database that tracks these people categorizes them as “missionaries” or “bluebeards,” among others.
questions.text: One database that tracks these people categorizes them as “missionaries” or “bluebeards,” among others. Former FBI agent Robert Ressler is credited with coining the term referring to these people. These people are ten times more likely to be male than female, although female ones like Aileen Wuornos do exist. It is estimated that there could be anywhere from 25-50 of these people active in the United States at any given time. Some famous examples of these people are Ed Gein, Ted Bundy, and the Zodiac. For ten points, name this type of criminal, who commits three or more murders with a cooling-off period between each one.

questions.first_sentence: A similar phenomenon to this is called a dry line. Lines of thunderstorms known as “squall lines” occur along a certain type of this phenomenon and they are typically associated with low pressure troughs.
questions.text: A similar phenomenon to this is called a dry line. Lines of thunderstorms known as “squall lines” occur along a certain type of this phenomenon and they are typically associated with low pressure troughs. A stationary form typically results in broader isotherm packing and rapid trowals form when one of these entities overtakes another in their occluded form. Commonly represented on maps using lines with either triangles or half circles, these entities typically can be classified by their humidity and air densities. questions.text: This document inspired Maya Angelou's "To Form a More Perfect Union," which was carried by a torch relay to a 1977 conference in Houston. For 10 points, name this 1848 document drafted at the Seneca Falls Convention.

questions.first_sentence: This town lends its name to a 1910 exhibition in New York of the paintings of Lawton Parker, Richard Miller, and Guy Rose.

The death of his oldest daughter and his diagnosis with a heart condition inspired the giant wooden mallet in his sixth symphony which delivers three blows of fate. questions.first_sentence: Alan Hajek "waged war" on it by suggesting a mixed strategy: make the decision based on whether you win the lottery.
questions.text: Alan Hajek "waged war" on it by suggesting a mixed strategy: make the decision based on whether you win the lottery.  His suggested fixes were to require overriding utility and distinguishable expectations.  Diderot's contemperaneous objection was that it assumed the existance of a single entity, and Schlesinger attempted to refute the "many gods" critique by arguing that its formulator's God was more probable than any other.  Assuming a payoff matrix with an infinite gain regardless of how small the probability, for ten points, is what philosophical argument for God by French mathematician?

questions.first_sentence: Many creation myths from this country refer to the first sunrise with the phrase “Zep Tepi.
questions.text: Many creation myths from this country refer to the first sunrise with the phrase “Zep Tepi.” A creation myth from this country holds that human beings were formed from the tears of a disobedient eye that was separated from its holder. Atum created the first deities, Shu and Tefnut, in a myth that originated in this country’s city of Heliopolis. For 10 points, name this country where other myths explain the origins of Osiris.

questions.text: These molecules can undergo a change called remolding or recruitment, perhaps explaining why only twenty two varieties of these molecules are encoded in mitochondrial DNA. The secondary structure of these molecules is often visualized as a clover leaf. Amino acids are carried to the ribosome by, for 10 points, what molecules that bind to mRNA during translation?

questions.text: An experiment using Chara provided evidence for the pressure-based model of the impact of this phenomenon, by which it can reverse the polarity of cytoplasmic streaming. Generally, roots grow in the direction of this phenomenon, while stems grow in the opposite direction of this phenomenon. This phenomenon that, like light, names a “tropism” that prominently shapes plant development. For 10 points, name this fundamental force that pulls plants (and everything else on Earth) downward.

Surface morphology can be determined using the “scanning” variety of these devices, while their “transmission” variety requires the use of an ultrathin sample. questions.first_sentence: Caffarelli et al. showed that a singularity predicted by these equations would not exist for any finite duration of time.
questions.text: Caffarelli et al. showed that a singularity predicted by these equations would not exist for any finite duration of time. They are the subject of a widely cited 1968 paper by Alexandre Chorin. By starting with these equations in three dimensional cylindrical coordinates, one can apply Newton’s first law to derive the Hagen-Poiseuille equation. The “existence and smoothness” problem of completely solving these equations is one of the Millenium Prize problems. Unlike the Euler equations, non-inviscid flow is described by, for 10 points, what equations that describe viscous fluid motion?

questions.first_sentence: A speculative NASA project seeks to send small, spiky, “hedgehog” probes to explore a moon of this planet.

Asaph Hall discovered this planet’s moons, which were photographed by the rovers Spirit and Opportunity. For 10 points, identify this planet whose two moons are named Deimos and Phobos.

questions.first_sentence: A version of this formula is used in the first step of deriving the Black-Scholes model to establish the equation for delta V. Faa di Bruno's formula is a higher-level generalization of this formula, whose counterpart in stochastic calculus is called Ito’s Lemma.
questions.text: A version of this formula is used in the first step of deriving the Black-Scholes model to establish the equation for delta V. Faa di Bruno's formula is a higher-level generalization of this formula, whose counterpart in stochastic calculus is called Ito’s Lemma. By this formula, the Jacobian of the composition of two functions is equal to the product of each function’s Jacobian. Using this rule and the product rule, one can derive the quotient rule. For 10 points, name this calculus “rule” which states that the derivative of f of g of x is f prime of g of x multiplied by g prime of x.

questions.first_sentence: In eastern Europe, many Jews craft this substance into the shape of a bird or a ladder during Rosh Hashanah.

Because of the haste of the Exodus from Egypt, Jews prepared an unleavened form of this food that is today eaten during Passover. questions.text: The leader of this country for much of the 2000s used a campaign slogan of “Peace and Love.” In November 2018, a politician in this country reversed his pledge to combine its environmental and agriculture ministries. questions.first_sentence: In this city, a vase showing marching soldiers in full armor, the Warrior Crater, was discovered in Grave Circle A. questions.text: In this city, a vase showing marching soldiers in full armor, the Warrior Crater, was discovered in Grave Circle A. A stone archway whose top depicts two lions forms a gate in this city, which contains nine surviving tholos tombs including the Treasury of Atreus and is nearby the similar site of Tiryns. A gold funerary mask was unearthed in this city by Heinrich Schliemann. A culture named for this city used the Linear B script and was the final dominant culture of Bronze Age Greece. For 10 points, name this city where the Mask of Agamemnon was unearthed.

questions.first_sentence: A painting in this location that renders silver shillings strewn on the floor in gold paint is titled Art and Money, and contains a characteristic blue-green background.
questions.text: A painting in this location that renders silver shillings strewn on the floor in gold paint is titled Art and Money, and contains a characteristic blue-green background. In this location, a painting of a white woman in a pink and grey kimono hangs above a fireplace. The design of this location ignited its creator’s feud with Frederick Leyland. This location, which is currently in the Freer Gallery at the Smithsonian, contains The Princess from the Land of Porcelain. For 10 points, identify this Asian-inspired room designed by James Whistler, which is named for a colorful bird.

questions.first_sentence: In 2017, scientists unearthed a complete ichthyosaur skeleton in this country, which is unusual since it is not a far northern country.
questions.text: In 2017, scientists unearthed a complete ichthyosaur skeleton in this country, which is unusual since it is not a far northern country. The Lameta Formation is in this country, whose central region contains a series of “Traps” that formed 66 million years ago around the time of the K-T Extinction. This country and Madagascar share many dinosaur species, since the tectonic plate named for this country was joined with Madagascar before it drifted northward and collided with Asia. For 10 points, name this country where Rajasaurus was discovered in Gujarat.

questions.first_sentence: This novel’s narrator lies about being a wrestler to borrow ten dollars from a Mexican driver before stating this book’s final line, “I been away a long time.
questions.text: This novel’s narrator lies about being a wrestler to borrow ten dollars from a Mexican driver before stating this book’s final line, “I been away a long time.” A man in this novel sees a rag on a tree branch, reminding him of his first sexual encounter at ten years old, while on a fishing trip that he coordinates with the prostitute Candy Starr. Billy Bibbit commits suicide after losing his virginity in this novel that contains a climactic scene in which Chief Bromden smothers the lobotomized Randle McMurphy. For 10 points, name this Ken Kesey novel mostly set in a mental asylum.

questions.first_sentence: The diary describes this battle with a page for each death in Tanya Savicheva's family.
questions.text: The diary describes this battle with a page for each death in Tanya Savicheva's family. The Green Belt of Glory monument commemorates this battle, during which the attackers were led by Wilhelm Ritter von Leeb. Dmitri Shostakovich's Seventh Symphony premiered during and is named after this battle. The defending side at this battle established the Road of Life to transport supplies across the frozen top of Lake Ladoga. For 10 points, name this siege during which a northern Russian city was attacked by German and Finnish forces during World War Two.

questions.first_sentence: Yoram Ben-Porath introduced a production function for this concept to predict its rate of creation.
questions.text: Yoram Ben-Porath introduced a production function for this concept to predict its rate of creation.
